9.1.1.2 Target NG-RAN node To Source NG-RAN node Transparent Container IE Semantics: Either includes the HandoverCommand message as defined in subclause 10.2.2 of TS 36.331 [14], if the target NG-RAN node is an ng-eNB, or the HandoverCommand message as defined in subclause 11.2.2 of TS 38.331 [10], if the target NG-RAN node is a gNB.

9.2.3.68 UE Context Kept Indicator - Section Description: This IE indicates whether the UE Context is kept at the S-NG-RAN node in case of an M-NG-RAN node handover without S-NG-RAN node change. 8.2.1 Handover Preparation 8.2.1.2 Successful Operation If the UE Context Reference at the S-NG-RAN IE is contained in the HANDOVER REQUEST message the target NG-RAN node may use it as specified in TS 37.340 [8]. In this case, the source NG-RAN node may expect the target NG-RAN node to include the UE Context Kept Indicator IE set to "True" in the HANDOVER REQUEST ACKNOWLEDGE message, which shall use this information as specified in TS 37.340 [8]. If the UE Context Kept Indicator IE set to "True" and the DRBs transferred to MN IE are included in the HANDOVER REQUEST ACKNOWLEDGE message, the source NG-RAN node shall, if supported, include the uplink/downlink PDCP SN and HFN status received from the S-NG-RAN node in the SN Status Transfer procedure towards the target NG-RAN node, as specified in TS 37.340 [8].

9.2.3.3 Criticality Diagnostics - Section Description: The Criticality Diagnostics IE is sent by the NG-RAN node when parts of a received message have not been comprehended or were missing, or if the message contained logical errors. When applicable, it contains information about which IEs were not comprehended or were missing.

9.2.3.3 Procedure Code IE Semantics: Procedure Code is to be used if Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure, and not within the response message of the same procedure that caused the error.
ENUMERATED (initiating message, successful outcome, unsuccessful outcome)
9.2.3.3 Triggering Message IE Semantics: The Triggering Message is used only if the Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure.
9.2.3.3 Procedure Criticality IE Semantics: This Procedure Criticality is used for reporting the Criticality of the Triggering message (Procedure).
9.2.3.3 IE Criticality IE Semantics: The IE Criticality is used for reporting the criticality of the triggering IE. The value "ignore" is not applicable.
9.2.3.3 IE ID IE Semantics: The IE ID of the not understood or missing IE

9.1.1.2 DRBs transferred to MN IE Semantics: In case of DC, indicates that SN Status is needed for the listed DRBs from the S-NG-RAN node. 9.2.1.29 DRB List - Section Description: This IE contains a list of DRBs. 8.2.1 Handover Preparation 8.2.1.2 Successful Operation If the UE Context Kept Indicator IE set to "True" and the DRBs transferred to MN IE are included in the HANDOVER REQUEST ACKNOWLEDGE message, the source NG-RAN node shall, if supported, include the uplink/downlink PDCP SN and HFN status received from the S-NG-RAN node in the SN Status Transfer procedure towards the target NG-RAN node, as specified in TS 37.340 [8].

9.2.3.33 DRB ID - Section Description: This IE contains the DRB ID. 8.2.1 Handover Preparation 8.2.1.2 Successful Operation For each DRB for which the source NG-RAN node proposes to perform forwarding of downlink data, the source NG-RAN node shall include the DRB ID IE and the mapped QoS Flows List IE within the Source DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List IE contained in the PDU Session Resources To Be Setup List IE in the HANDOVER REQUEST message. The source NG-RAN node may include the QoS Flow Mapping Indication IE in the Source DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List IE to indicate that only the uplink or downlink QoS flow is mapped to the DRB. If the target NG-RAN node decides to use the same DRB configuration and to map the same QoS flows as the source NG-RAN node, the target NG-RAN node includes the DL Forwarding GTP Tunnel Endpoint IE within the Data Forwarding Response DRB List IE in the HANDOVER REQUEST ACKNOWLEDGE message to indicate that it accepts the proposed forwarding of downlink data for this DRB.

section_list.name: HANDOVER PREPARATION FAILURE
aoa:
This message is sent by the target NG-RAN node to inform the source NG-RAN node that the Handover Preparation has failed.
Direction: target NG-RAN node ? source NG-RAN node.
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)

9.1.1.3 Source NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID IE Semantics: Allocated at the source NG-RAN node 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.

9.2.3.2 Cause - Section Description: The purpose of the Cause IE is to indicate the reason for a particular event for the XnAP protocol. 8.2.1 Handover Preparation 8.2.1.3 Unsuccessful Operation If the target NG-RAN node does not admit at least one PDU session resource, or a failure occurs during the Handover Preparation, the target NG-RAN node shall send the HANDOVER PREPARATION FAILURE message to the source NG-RAN node. The message shall contain the Cause IE with an appropriate value. If there is no response from the target NG-RAN node to the HANDOVER REQUEST message before timer TXnRELOCprep expires in the source NG-RAN node, the source NG-RAN node should cancel the Handover Preparation procedure towards the target NG-RAN node by initiating the Handover Cancel procedure with the appropriate value for the Cause IE. The source NG-RAN node shall ignore any HANDOVER REQUEST ACKNOWLEDGE or HANDOVER PREPARATION FAILURE message received after the initiation of the Handover Cancel procedure and remove any reference and release any resources related to the concerned Xn UE-associated signalling.

ENUMERATED ( Cell not Available, Handover Desirable for Radio Reasons, Handover Target not Allowed, Invalid AMF Set ID, No Radio Resources Available in Target Cell, Partial Handover, Reduce Load in Serving Cell, Resource Optimisation Handover, Time Critical Handover, TXnRELOCoverall Expiry, TXnRELOCprep Expiry, Unknown GUAMI ID, Unknown Local NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, Inconsistent Remote NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, Encryption And/Or Integrity Protection Algorithms Not Supported, Protection Algorithms Not Supported, Multiple PDU Session ID Instances, Unknown PDU Session ID, Unknown QoS Flow ID, Multiple QoS Flow ID Instances, Switch Off Ongoing, Not supported 5QI value, TXnDCoverall Expiry, TXnDCprep Expiry, Action Desirable for Radio Reasons, Reduce Load, Resource Optimisation, Time Critical action, Target not Allowed, No Radio Resources Available, Invalid QoS combination, Encryption Algorithms Not Supported, Procedure cancelled, RRM purpose, Improve User Bit Rate, User Inactivity, Radio Connection With UE Lost, Failure in the Radio Interface Procedure, Bearer Option not Supported, UP integrity protection not possible, UP confidentiality protection not possible, Resources not available for the slice (s), UE Maximum integrity protected data rate reason, CP Integrity Protection Failure, UP Integrity Protection Failure, Slice (s) not supported by NG-RAN, MN Mobility, SN Mobility, Count reaches max value, Unknown Old NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, PDCP Overload, DRB ID not available, Unspecified, …, UE Context ID not known, Non-relocation of context)

ENUMERATED (Transfer Syntax Error, Abstract Syntax Error (Reject), Abstract Syntax Error (Ignore and Notify), Message not Compatible with Receiver State, Semantic Error, Abstract Syntax Error (Falsely Constructed Message), Unspecified, …)
ENUMERATED (Control Processing Overload, Hardware Failure, O&M Intervention, Not enough User Plane Processing Resources, Unspecified, …)

9.2.3.3 Criticality Diagnostics - Section Description: The Criticality Diagnostics IE is sent by the NG-RAN node when parts of a received message have not been comprehended or were missing, or if the message contained logical errors. When applicable, it contains information about which IEs were not comprehended or were missing.

9.2.3.3 Procedure Code IE Semantics: Procedure Code is to be used if Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure, and not within the response message of the same procedure that caused the error.
ENUMERATED (initiating message, successful outcome, unsuccessful outcome)
9.2.3.3 Triggering Message IE Semantics: The Triggering Message is used only if the Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure.
9.2.3.3 Procedure Criticality IE Semantics: This Procedure Criticality is used for reporting the Criticality of the Triggering message (Procedure).
9.2.3.3 IE Criticality IE Semantics: The IE Criticality is used for reporting the criticality of the triggering IE. The value "ignore" is not applicable.
9.2.3.3 IE ID IE Semantics: The IE ID of the not understood or missing IE

section_list.name: SN STATUS TRANSFER
aoa:
This message is sent by the source NG-RAN node to the target NG-RAN node to transfer the uplink/downlink PDCP SN and HFN status during a handover or for dual connectivity.
Direction:	source NG-RAN node ? target NG-RAN node(handover),
NG-RAN node from which the DRB context is transferred ? NG-RAN node to which the DRB context is transferred (RRC connection re-establishment or dual connectivity).
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)

9.1.1.4 Source NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID IE Semantics: Allocated for handover at the source NG-RAN node and for dual connectivity at the NG-RAN node from which the DRB context is transferred. 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.

9.1.1.4 Target NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID IE Semantics: Allocated for handover at the target NG-RAN node and for dual connectivity at the NG-RAN node to which the DRB context is transferred. 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.

9.2.1.14 DRBs Subject To Status Transfer List - Section Description: This IE contains a list of DRBs containing information about PDCP PDU transfer status. 8.2.2 SN Status Transfer 8.2.2.2 Successful Operation For each DRB for which PDCP-SN and HFN status preservation applies, the source NG-RAN node shall include the DRB ID IE, the UL COUNT Value IE and the DL COUNT Value IE within the DRBs Subject To Status Transfer List IE in the SN STATUS TRANSFER message. If the SN STATUS TRANSFER message contains in the DRBs Subject To Status Transfer List IE the Old QoS Flow List - UL End Marker expected IE, the target NG-RAN shall be prepared to receive the SDAP end marker for the QoS flow via the corresponding DRB, as specified in TS 38.300 [8].

9.2.3.33 DRB ID - Section Description: This IE contains the DRB ID. 8.2.2 SN Status Transfer 8.2.2.2 Successful Operation For each DRB for which PDCP-SN and HFN status preservation applies, the source NG-RAN node shall include the DRB ID IE, the UL COUNT Value IE and the DL COUNT Value IE within the DRBs Subject to Status Transfer List IE in the SN STATUS TRANSFER message.

9.2.1.14 Receive Status Of PDCP SDU IE Semantics: The IE is used in case of 12-bit long PDCP-SN. The first bit indicates the status of the SDU after the First Missing UL PDCP SDU. The Nth bit indicates the status of the UL PDCP SDU in position (N + First Missing SDU Number) modulo (1 + the maximum value of the PDCP-SN). 0: PDCP SDU has not been received. 1: PDCP SDU has been received correctly.

9.2.1.14 UL COUNT Value IE Semantics: PDCP-SN and Hyper Frame Number of the first missing UL SDU in case of 12-bit long PDCP-SN 9.2.3.36 COUNT Value for PDCP SN Length 12 - Section Description: This information element indicates the 12-bit long PDCP sequence number and the corresponding 20 bits long Hyper Frame Number. 8.2.2 SN Status Transfer 8.2.2.2 Successful Operation For each DRB for which PDCP-SN and HFN status preservation applies, the source NG-RAN node shall include the DRB ID IE, the UL COUNT Value IE and the DL COUNT Value IE within the DRBs Subject to Status Transfer List IE in the SN STATUS TRANSFER message.

9.2.1.14 Receive Status Of PDCP SDU IE Semantics: The IE is used in case of 18-bit long PDCP-SN. The first bit indicates the status of the SDU after the First Missing UL PDCP SDU. The Nth bit indicates the status of the UL PDCP SDU in position (N + First Missing SDU Number) modulo (1 + the maximum value of the PDCP-SN). 0: PDCP SDU has not been received. 1: PDCP SDU has been received correctly.

9.2.1.14 UL COUNT Value IE Semantics: PDCP-SN and Hyper Frame Number of the first missing UL SDU in case of 18-bit long PDCP-SN 9.2.3.37 COUNT Value for PDCP SN Length 18 - Section Description: This information element indicates the 18-bit long PDCP sequence number and the corresponding 14 bits long Hyper Frame Number. 8.2.2 SN Status Transfer 8.2.2.2 Successful Operation For each DRB for which PDCP-SN and HFN status preservation applies, the source NG-RAN node shall include the DRB ID IE, the UL COUNT Value IE and the DL COUNT Value IE within the DRBs Subject to Status Transfer List IE in the SN STATUS TRANSFER message.

9.2.1.14 DL COUNT Value IE Semantics: PDCP-SN and Hyper Frame Number that the target NG-RAN node (handover) or the NG-RAN node to which the DRB context is transferred (dual connectivity) should assign for the next DL SDU not having an SN yet in case of 12-bit long PDCP-SN 9.2.3.36 COUNT Value for PDCP SN Length 12 - Section Description: This information element indicates the 12-bit long PDCP sequence number and the corresponding 20 bits long Hyper Frame Number. 8.2.2 SN Status Transfer 8.2.2.2 Successful Operation For each DRB for which PDCP-SN and HFN status preservation applies, the source NG-RAN node shall include the DRB ID IE, the UL COUNT Value IE and the DL COUNT Value IE within the DRBs Subject to Status Transfer List IE in the SN STATUS TRANSFER message.

9.2.1.14 DL COUNT Value IE Semantics: PDCP-SN and Hyper Frame Number that the target NG-RAN node (handover) or the NG-RAN node to which the DRB context is transferred (dual connectivity) should assign for the next DL SDU not having an SN yet in case of 18-bit long PDCP-SN 9.2.3.37 COUNT Value for PDCP SN Length 18 - Section Description: This information element indicates the 18-bit long PDCP sequence number and the corresponding 14 bits long Hyper Frame Number. 8.2.2 SN Status Transfer 8.2.2.2 Successful Operation For each DRB for which PDCP-SN and HFN status preservation applies, the source NG-RAN node shall include the DRB ID IE, the UL COUNT Value IE and the DL COUNT Value IE within the DRBs Subject to Status Transfer List IE in the SN STATUS TRANSFER message.
└─Old QoS Flow List - UL End Marker expected

9.2.1.14 Old QoS Flow List - UL End Marker expected IE Semantics: This IE is included to be used for indicating that the source NG-RAN node has initiated QoS flow re-mapping and has not yet received SDAP end markers, as described in TS 38.300 [8]. 9.2.1.4a QoS Flow List - Section Description: This IE contains a list of QoS flows. 8.2.2 SN Status Transfer 8.2.2.2 Successful Operation If the SN STATUS TRANSFER message contains in the DRBs Subject To Status Transfer List IE the Old QoS Flow List - UL End Marker expected IE, the target NG-RAN shall be prepared to receive the SDAP end marker for the QoS flow via the corresponding DRB, as specified in TS 38.300 [8].
9.2.3.10 QoS Flow Identifier - Section Description: This IE identifies a QoS Flow within a PDU Session. Definition and use of the QoS Flow Identifier is specified in TS 23.501 [7].

section_list.name: UE CONTEXT RELEASE
aoa:
This message is sent by the target NG-RAN node to the source NG-RAN node to indicate that resources can be released.
Direction: target NG-RAN node ? source NG-RAN node, M-NG-RAN node ? S-NG-RAN node.
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)

9.1.1.5 Source NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID IE Semantics: Allocated for handover at the source NG-RAN node or for dual connectivity at the S-NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.

9.1.1.5 Target NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID IE Semantics: Allocated for handover at the target NG-RAN node or for dual connectivity at the M-NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.

section_list.name: HANDOVER CANCEL
aoa:
This message is sent by the source NG-RAN node to the target NG-RAN node to cancel an ongoing handover.
Direction: source NG-RAN node ? target NG-RAN node.
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)

9.1.1.6 Source NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID IE Semantics: Allocated at the source NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.

9.1.1.6 Target NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID IE Semantics: Allocated at the target NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.
9.2.3.2 Cause - Section Description: The purpose of the Cause IE is to indicate the reason for a particular event for the XnAP protocol.

ENUMERATED ( Cell not Available, Handover Desirable for Radio Reasons, Handover Target not Allowed, Invalid AMF Set ID, No Radio Resources Available in Target Cell, Partial Handover, Reduce Load in Serving Cell, Resource Optimisation Handover, Time Critical Handover, TXnRELOCoverall Expiry, TXnRELOCprep Expiry, Unknown GUAMI ID, Unknown Local NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, Inconsistent Remote NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, Encryption And/Or Integrity Protection Algorithms Not Supported, Protection Algorithms Not Supported, Multiple PDU Session ID Instances, Unknown PDU Session ID, Unknown QoS Flow ID, Multiple QoS Flow ID Instances, Switch Off Ongoing, Not supported 5QI value, TXnDCoverall Expiry, TXnDCprep Expiry, Action Desirable for Radio Reasons, Reduce Load, Resource Optimisation, Time Critical action, Target not Allowed, No Radio Resources Available, Invalid QoS combination, Encryption Algorithms Not Supported, Procedure cancelled, RRM purpose, Improve User Bit Rate, User Inactivity, Radio Connection With UE Lost, Failure in the Radio Interface Procedure, Bearer Option not Supported, UP integrity protection not possible, UP confidentiality protection not possible, Resources not available for the slice (s), UE Maximum integrity protected data rate reason, CP Integrity Protection Failure, UP Integrity Protection Failure, Slice (s) not supported by NG-RAN, MN Mobility, SN Mobility, Count reaches max value, Unknown Old NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, PDCP Overload, DRB ID not available, Unspecified, …, UE Context ID not known, Non-relocation of context)

ENUMERATED (Transfer Syntax Error, Abstract Syntax Error (Reject), Abstract Syntax Error (Ignore and Notify), Message not Compatible with Receiver State, Semantic Error, Abstract Syntax Error (Falsely Constructed Message), Unspecified, …)
ENUMERATED (Control Processing Overload, Hardware Failure, O&M Intervention, Not enough User Plane Processing Resources, Unspecified, …)

section_list.name: RAN PAGING
aoa:
This message is sent by the NG-RAN node1 to NG-RAN node2 to page a UE.
Direction: NG-RAN node1 ? NG-RAN node2.
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)
9.1.1.7 Index Length-10 IE Semantics: Coded as specified in TS 38.304 [33] and TS 36.304 [34].
9.2.3.43 UE RAN Paging Identity - Section Description: The IE defines the UE Identity for RAN paging a UE in RRC_INACTIVE.
9.2.3.66 Paging DRX - Section Description: This IE indicates the Paging DRX as defined in TS 38.304 [33] and TS 36.304 [34].
9.2.3.38 RAN Paging Area - Section Description: The RAN Paging Area IE defines the paging area within a PLMN for RAN paging a UE in RRC_INACTIVE state.

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).

9.2.3.38 NG-RAN Cell Identity IE Semantics: In this version of the specification, the RAN paging area should contain NG-RAN cells of the same RAT type. 9.2.2.9 NG-RAN Cell Identity - Section Description: This IE contains either an NR or an E-UTRA Cell Identity.
9.2.2.9 NR Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE correspond to the gNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.1).
9.2.2.9 E-UTRA Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE correspond to the ng-eNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.8).
9.2.3.39 RAN Area ID - Section Description: This IE defines the RAN Area ID.
9.2.3.39 TAC IE Semantics: Tracking Area Code 9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.
9.2.2.6 RAN Area Code - Section Description: This IE defines the RAN Area Code.
ENUMERATED (PrioLevel1, PrioLevel2, PrioLevel3, PrioLevel4, PrioLevel5, PrioLevel6, PrioLevel7, PrioLevel8, ...)

9.2.3.44 Paging Priority - Section Description: This information element contains an indication of the priority to be considered for the paging request. 9.2.3.44 Paging Priority IE Semantics: Lower value codepoint indicates higher priority. 8.2.5 RAN Paging 8.2.5.2 Successful operation If the Paging Priority IE is included in the RAN PAGING message, the NG-RAN node2 may use it to prioritize paging.

9.2.3.41 Assistance Data for RAN Paging - Section Description: This IE provides assistance information for RAN paging. 8.2.5 RAN Paging 8.2.5.2 Successful operation If the Assistance Data for RAN Paging IE is included in the RAN PAGING message, the NG-RAN node2 may use it according to TS 38.300 [9].
9.2.3.42 RAN Paging Attempt Information - Section Description: This IE includes information related to the RAN paging attempt over Xn.
9.2.3.42 Paging Attempt Count IE Semantics: Number of the RAN paging attempt.
9.2.3.42 Intended Number of Paging Attempts IE Semantics: Intended number of RAN paging attempts.
9.2.3.42 Next Paging Area Scope IE Semantics: Indicates whether the RAN paging area scope will change at next RAN paging attempt.

9.2.3.91 UE Radio Capability for Paging - Section Description: This IE contains paging specific UE Radio Capability information. 8.2.5 RAN Paging 8.2.5.2 Successful operation If the UE Radio Capability for Paging IE is included in the RAN PAGING message, the NG-RAN node2 may use it to apply specific paging schemes.
├─UE Radio Capability for Paging of NR
9.2.3.91 UE Radio Capability for Paging of NR IE Semantics: Includes the RRC UERadioPagingInformation message as defined in TS 38.331 [18].
└─UE Radio Capability for Paging of E-UTRA
9.2.3.91 UE Radio Capability for Paging of E-UTRA IE Semantics: Includes the RRC UERadioPagingInformation message as defined in TS 36.331 [21].

section_list.name: RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT REQUEST
aoa:
This message is sent by the new NG-RAN node to request the old NG-RAN node to transfer the UE Context to the new NG-RAN.
Direction: new NG-RAN node ? old NG-RAN node.
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)
├─New NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID reference

9.1.1.8 New NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID reference IE Semantics: Allocated at the new NG-RAN node 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.
9.2.3.40 UE Context ID - Section Description: This IE is used to address a UE Context within an NG-RAN node.

9.2.3.40 I-RNTI IE Semantics: NOTE: How the new NG-RAN node is able to resolve the old NG-RAN ID from the I-RNTI is a matter of proper configuration in the old and new NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.46 I-RNTI - Section Description: The I-RNTI is defined for allocation in an NR or E-UTRA serving cell as a reference to a UE Context within an NG-RAN node. The I-RNTI is partitioned into two parts, the first part identifies the NG-RAN node that allocated the I-RNTI and the second part identifies the UE context stored in this NG-RAN node.

9.2.3.46 I-RNTI full IE Semantics: This IE is used to identify the suspended UE context of a UE in RRC_INACTIVE using 40 bits (refer to I-RNTI-Value IE in TS 38.331 [10] and I-RNTI IE in TS 36.331 [14]).

9.2.3.46 I-RNTI short IE Semantics: This IE is used to identify the suspended UE context of a UE in RRC_INACTIVE using 24 bits (refer to ShortI-RNTI-Value IE in TS 38.331 [10] and ShortI-RNTI IE in TS 36.331 [14]).

9.2.3.40 Allocated C-RNTI IE Semantics: Temporary C-RNTI allocated to the UE by the cell where the RRC connection has been requested to be resumed, contained in the MAC RAR as defined in TS 38.321 [35] or in TS 36.321 [36].

9.2.3.40 Access PCI IE Semantics: The cell PCI where the RRC connection has been requested to be resumed. 9.2.2.10 NG-RAN Cell PCI - Section Description: This IE defines physical cell ID of a cell served by an NG-RAN node.
9.2.2.10 NR PCI IE Semantics: NR Physical Cell ID
9.2.2.10 E-UTRA PCI IE Semantics: E-UTRA Physical Cell ID
9.2.3.40 C-RNTI IE Semantics: C-RNTI contained in the RRCReestablishmentRequest message (TS 38.331 [10]) or RRCConnectionReestablishmentRequest message (TS 36.331 [14]).
9.2.2.10 NG-RAN Cell PCI - Section Description: This IE defines physical cell ID of a cell served by an NG-RAN node.
9.2.2.10 NR PCI IE Semantics: NR Physical Cell ID
9.2.2.10 E-UTRA PCI IE Semantics: E-UTRA Physical Cell ID

9.1.1.8 Integrity protection IE Semantics: RRC Resume: ResumeMAC-I either contained in the RRC ResumeRequest or the RRCResumeRequest1 message as defined in TS 38.331 [10]) or the ShortResumeMAC-I in the RRCConnection ResumeRequest message as defined in TS 36.331 [14]) RRC Reestablishment: ShortMAC-I contained in the RRCReestablishmentRequest as defined in TS 38.331 [10]) or the ShortMAC-I in the RRCConnection ReestablishmentRequest message as defined in TS 36.331 [14]).

9.1.1.8 New Cell Identifier IE Semantics: RRC Resume: Corresponds to the targetCellIdentity within the VarResumeMAC-Input as specified in TS 38.331 [10] or the cellIdentity within the VarShortINACTIVE-MAC-Input as specified in TS 36.331 [14]. RRC Reestablishment: Corresponds to the targetCellIdentity within the VarShortMAC-Input as specified in TS 38.331 [10] or the cellIdentity within the VarShortMAC-Input as specified in TS 36.331 [14]. 9.2.2.9 NG-RAN Cell Identity - Section Description: This IE contains either an NR or an E-UTRA Cell Identity.
9.2.2.9 NR Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE correspond to the gNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.1).
9.2.2.9 E-UTRA Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE correspond to the ng-eNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.8).

9.1.1.8 RRC Resume Cause IE Semantics: In case of RNA Update, contains the cause value provided by the UE in the RRCResumeRequest or the RRCResumeRequest1 message, as defined in TS 38.331 [10], or in the RRCConnection ResumeRequest message, as defined in TS 36.331 [14]. 9.2.3.61 RRC Resume Cause - Section Description: The purpose of the RRC Resume Cause IE is to indicate to the old NG-RAN node the reason for the RRC Connection Resume as received from the UE in the ResumeCause defined in TS 36.331 [14] and TS 38.331 [10]. In this version of the specification, this is limited to the case of RNA update.

section_list.name: RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT RESPONSE
aoa:
This message is sent by the old NG-RAN node to transfer the UE context to the new NG-RAN node.
Direction: old NG-RAN node ? new NG-RAN node.
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)
├─New NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID reference

9.1.1.9 New NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID reference IE Semantics: Allocated at the new NG-RAN node 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.
├─Old NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID reference

9.1.1.9 Old NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID reference IE Semantics: Allocated at the old NG-RAN node 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.
9.2.3.24 GUAMI - Section Description: This IE contains the Globally Unique AMF Identifier (GUAMI) as defined in TS 23.003 [22].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
├─UE Context Information – Retrieve UE Context Response
9.2.1.13 UE Context Information - Retrieve UE Context Response - Section Description: This IE contains the UE context information within the RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT RESPONSE message.

9.2.1.13 NG-C UE associated Signalling reference IE Semantics: Allocated at the AMF on the old NG-C connection. 9.2.3.26 AMF UE NGAP ID - Section Description: This IE is defined in TS 38.413 [5] and used to uniquely identify the UE association over the source side NG interface instance.
│  ├─Signalling TNL Association Address at source NG-C side

9.2.1.13 Signalling TNL Association Address at source NG-C side IE Semantics: This IE indicates the AMF’s IP address of the SCTP association used at the source NG-C interface instance. Note: If no UE TNLA binding exists at the source NG-RAN node, the source NG-RAN node indicates the TNL association address it would have selected if it would have had to create a UE TNLA binding. 9.2.3.31 CP Transport Layer Information - Section Description: This element is used to provide the transport layer information associated with NG or Xn control plane transport.
9.2.3.29 Transport Layer Address - Section Description: This IE is defined to contain an IP address.
9.2.3.29 Transport Layer Address - Section Description: This IE is defined to contain an IP address.
9.2.3.49 UE Security Capabilities - Section Description: The UE Security Capabilities IE defines the supported algorithms for encryption and integrity protection in the UE.

9.2.3.49 NR Encryption Algorithms IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents an encryption algorithm: “all bits equal to 0” – UE supports no other NR algorithm than NEA0, “first bit” – 128-NEA1, “second bit” – 128-NEA2, “third bit” – 128-NEA3, other bits reserved for future use. Value ‘1’ indicates support and value ‘0’ indicates no support of the algorithm. Algorithms are defined in TS 33.501 [28].

9.2.3.49 NR Integrity Protection Algorithms IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents an integrity protection algorithm: “all bits equal to 0” – UE supports no other NR algorithm than NIA0, “first bit” – 128-NIA1, “second bit” – 128-NIA2, “third bit” – 128-NIA3, other bits reserved for future use. Value ‘1’ indicates support and value ‘0’ indicates no support of the algorithm. Algorithms are defined in TS 33.501 [28].

9.2.3.49 E-UTRA Encryption Algorithms IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents an encryption algorithm: “all bits equal to 0” – UE supports no other algorithm than EEA0, “first bit” – 128-EEA1, “second bit” – 128-EEA2, “third bit” – 128-EEA3, other bits reserved for future use. Value ‘1’ indicates support and value ‘0’ indicates no support of the algorithm. Algorithms are defined in TS 33.401 [29].

9.2.3.49 E-UTRA Integrity Protection Algorithms IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents an integrity protection algorithm: “all bits equal to 0” – UE supports no other algorithm than EIA0, “first bit” – 128-EIA1, “second bit” – 128-EIA2, “third bit” – 128-EIA3, other bits reserved for future use. Value ‘1’ indicates support and value ‘0’ indicates no support of the algorithm. Algorithms are defined in TS 33.401 [29].
9.2.3.50 AS Security Information - Section Description: The AS Security Information IE is used to generate the key material to be used for AS security with the UE.
9.2.3.50 Key NG-RAN Star IE Semantics: KNG-RAN* defined in TS 33.501 [28].
9.2.3.50 Next Hop Chaining Count IE Semantics: Next Hop Chaining Count (NCC) defined in TS 33.501 [28]

9.2.3.17 UE Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate - Section Description: The UE Aggregate Maximum Bitrate is applicable for all Non-GBR QoS flows per UE which is defined for the Downlink and the Uplink direction and a subscription parameter provided by the AMF to the NG-RAN. 9.2.3.17 UE Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate IE Semantics: Applicable for Non-GBR QoS flows.

9.2.3.17 UE Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate Downlink IE Semantics: This IE indicates the UE Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate as specified in TS 23.501 [7] in the downlink direction. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.17 UE Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate Uplink IE Semantics: This IE indicates the UE Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate as specified in TS 23.501 [7] in the uplink direction. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s
│  ├─PDU Session Resources To Be Setup List

9.2.1.1 PDU Session Resources To Be Setup List - Section Description: This IE contains PDU session resource related information used at UE context transfer between NG-RAN nodes. 8.2.4 Retrieve UE Context 8.2.4.2 Successful Operation For each QoS flow in the RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT RESPONSE message, if the QoS Monitoring Request IE is included in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE in the PDU Session Resources To Be Setup List IE, the new NG-RAN node shall store this information, and, if supported, perform delay measurement and QoS monitoring, as specified in TS 23.501 [7].
│  │  └─PDU Session Resources To Be Setup Item
9.2.3.18 PDU Session ID - Section Description: This IE identifies a PDU Session for a UE. Definition and use of the PDU Session ID is specified in TS 23.501 [7].
9.2.3.21 S-NSSAI - Section Description: This IE indicates the S-NSSAI as defined in TS 23.003 [22].

9.2.1.1 PDU Session Resource Aggregate Maximum Bitrate IE Semantics: This IE shall be present when at least one Non-GBR QoS Flow has been setup. 9.2.3.69 PDU Session Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE is applicable for all Non-GBR QoS flows per PDU session which is defined for the downlink and the uplink direction and is provided at the Handover Preparation procedure to the target NG-RAN node and at the Retrieve UE Context procedure to the new NG-RAN node as received by the 5GC, during dual connectivity related procedures to the to the S-NG-RAN node as decided by the M-NG-RAN node, as specified in TS 37.340 [8]. 9.2.3.69 PDU session Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate IE Semantics: Applicable for Non-GBR QoS flows.
│  │     │  ├─PDU session Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate Downlink

9.2.3.69 PDU session Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate Downlink IE Semantics: This IE indicates the PDU session Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate as specified in TS 23.501 [7] in the downlink direction. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s
│  │     │  └─PDU session Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate Uplink

9.2.3.69 PDU session Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate Uplink IE Semantics: This IE indicates the PDU session Aggregate Maximum Bit Rate as specified in TS 23.501 [7] in the uplink direction. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s
│  │     ├─UL NG-U UP TNL Information at UPF

9.2.1.1 UL NG-U UP TNL Information at UPF IE Semantics: UPF endpoint of the NG-U transport bearer. For delivery of UL PDUs 9.2.3.30 UP Transport Layer Information - Section Description: This element is used to provide the transport layer information associated with NG or Xn user plane transport. In this release it corresponds to an IP adress and a GTP Tunnel Endpoint Identifier.

9.2.3.30 Transport Layer Address IE Semantics: The Transport Layer Address is specified in TS 38.424 [19] and TS 38.414 [20]. 9.2.3.29 Transport Layer Address - Section Description: This IE is defined to contain an IP address.
9.2.3.30 GTP-TEID IE Semantics: The Tunnel Endpoint Identifier (TEID) is specified in TS 29.281 [18]
│  │     ├─Additional UL NG-U UP TNL Information at UPF List
9.2.1.1 Additional UL NG-U UP TNL Information at UPF List IE Semantics: Additional UPF endpoint of the NG-U transport bearer. For delivery of UL PDUs

9.2.1.1 Source DL NG-U TNL Information IE Semantics: Indicates the possibility to keep the NG-U GTP-U tunnel termination point at the target NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.30 UP Transport Layer Information - Section Description: This element is used to provide the transport layer information associated with NG or Xn user plane transport. In this release it corresponds to an IP adress and a GTP Tunnel Endpoint Identifier.

9.2.3.30 Transport Layer Address IE Semantics: The Transport Layer Address is specified in TS 38.424 [19] and TS 38.414 [20]. 9.2.3.29 Transport Layer Address - Section Description: This IE is defined to contain an IP address.
9.2.3.30 GTP-TEID IE Semantics: The Tunnel Endpoint Identifier (TEID) is specified in TS 29.281 [18]

9.2.3.52 Security Indication - Section Description: This IE contains the user plane integrity protection indication and confidentiality protection indication which indicates the requirements on UP integrity protection and ciphering for the corresponding PDU session, respectively. Additionally, this IE contains the maximum integrity protected data rate values (UL and DL) per UE for integrity protected DRBs.
9.2.3.52 Integrity Protection Indication IE Semantics: Indicates whether UP integrity protection shall apply, should apply, or shall not apply for the concerned PDU session.
9.2.3.52 Confidentiality Protection Indication IE Semantics: Indicates whether UP ciphering shall apply, should apply, or shall not apply for the concerned PDU session.

9.2.3.52 - Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate IE - ifIntegrityProtectionrequiredorpreferred: This IE shall be present if the Integrity Protection IE within the Security Indication IE is present and set to “required” or “preferred”. 9.2.3.52 Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate IE Semantics: If present, this IE contains the values received from the CN for the overall UE capability. This IE may be ignored by the SN in the case of dual connectivity. 9.2.3.73 Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the maximum aggregate data rate for integrity protected DRBs for a UE as defined in TS 38.300 [9].

9.2.3.73 Maximum IP Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum aggregate rate for integrity protected DRBs supported by the UE in UL. If the Maximum IP Rate Downlink IE is absent, this IE applies to both UL and DL. 9.2.3.89 Maximum IP Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the maximum aggregate data rate for integrity protected DRBs for a UE as defined in TS 38.300 [9]. 9.2.3.89 Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate IE Semantics: Defines the upper bound of the aggregate data rate of user plane integrity protected data.

9.2.3.73 Maximum IP Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum aggregate rate for integrity protected DRBs supported by the UE in the DL. 9.2.3.89 Maximum IP Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the maximum aggregate data rate for integrity protected DRBs for a UE as defined in TS 38.300 [9]. 9.2.3.89 Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate IE Semantics: Defines the upper bound of the aggregate data rate of user plane integrity protected data.
9.2.3.19 PDU Session Type - Section Description: This IE defines the PDU Session Type as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.1.1 Network Instance IE Semantics: This IE is ignored if the Common Network Instance IE is present. 9.2.3.85 Network Instance - Section Description: This IE provides the network instance to be used by the NG-RAN node when selecting a particular transport network resource as described in TS 23.501 [7].
9.2.3.10 QoS Flow Identifier - Section Description: This IE identifies a QoS Flow within a PDU Session. Definition and use of the QoS Flow Identifier is specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.5 QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters - Section Description: This IE defines the QoS Parameters to be applied to a QoS flow. 8.2.4 Retrieve UE Context 8.2.4.2 Successful Operation For each QoS flow in the RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT RESPONSE message, if the QoS Monitoring Request IE is included in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE in the PDU Session Resources To Be Setup List IE, the new NG-RAN node shall store this information, and, if supported, perform delay measurement and QoS monitoring, as specified in TS 23.501 [7].
9.2.3.8 Non dynamic 5QI Descriptor - Section Description: This IE defines QoS characteristics for a standardized or pre-configured 5QI for downlink and uplink.
9.2.3.8 5QI IE Semantics: This IE contains the standardized or pre-configured 5QI as specified in TS 23.501 [7}

9.2.3.8 Priority Level IE Semantics: Priority level is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. When included, it overrides standardized or pre-configured value. 9.2.3.62 Priority Level - Section Description: This IE indicates the Priority Level for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.62 Priority Level IE Semantics: Values ordered in decreasing order of priority, i.e. with 1 as the highest priority and 127 as the lowest priority.

9.2.3.8 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Averaging window is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. When included, it overrides standardized or pre-configured value. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window - Section Description: This IE indicates the Averaging Window for a QoS flow and applies to GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Unit: ms.

9.2.3.8 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Maximum Data Burst Volume is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. When included, it overrides standardized or pre-configured value. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume - Section Description: This IE indicates the Maximum Data Burst Volume for a QoS flow and applies to delay critical GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Unit: byte,
9.2.3.9 Dynamic 5QI Descriptor - Section Description: This IE defines the QoS characteristics for a non-standardized or not pre-configured 5QI for downlink and uplink.

9.2.3.9 Priority Level IE Semantics: Priority level is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.62 Priority Level - Section Description: This IE indicates the Priority Level for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.62 Priority Level IE Semantics: Values ordered in decreasing order of priority, i.e. with 1 as the highest priority and 127 as the lowest priority.

9.2.3.9 Packet Delay Budget IE Semantics: Packet Delay Budget is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.12 Packet Delay Budget - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Delay Budget for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.12 Packet Delay Budget IE Semantics: Upper bound value for the delay that a packet may experience expressed in units of 0.5ms.
9.2.3.9 Packet Error Rate IE Semantics: Packet Error Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.13 Packet Error Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Error Rate for a QoS flow.
9.2.3.13 Scalar IE Semantics: The packet error rate is expressed as Scalar * 10-k, whereas k is the Exponent.
9.2.3.9 5QI IE Semantics: This IE contains the dynamically assigned 5QI as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.9 - Delay Critical IE - ifGBRflow: This IE shall be present if the GBR QoS Flow Information IE is present in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE. 9.2.3.9 Delay Critical IE Semantics: This IE indicates whether the GBR QoS flow is delay critical as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.9 - Averaging Window IE - ifGBRflow: This IE shall be present if the GBR QoS Flow Information IE is present in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE. 9.2.3.9 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Averaging window is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window - Section Description: This IE indicates the Averaging Window for a QoS flow and applies to GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Unit: ms.

9.2.3.9 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Maximum Data Burst Volume is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. This IE shall be included if the Delay Critical IE is set to "delay critical" and is be ignored otherwise. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume - Section Description: This IE indicates the Maximum Data Burst Volume for a QoS flow and applies to delay critical GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Unit: byte,
9.2.3.7 Allocation and Retention Priority - Section Description: This IE specifies the relative importance compared to other QoS flows for allocation and retention of the NR RAN resource.

9.2.3.7 Priority Level IE Semantics: Desc.: This defines the relative importance of a resource request. (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: Values between 1 and 15 are ordered in decreasing order of priority, i.e., 1 is the highest and 15 is the lowest.
ENUMERATED (shall not trigger pre-emption, may trigger pre-emption, ...)

9.2.3.7 Pre-emption Capability IE Semantics: Desc.: This IE indicates the pre-emption capability of the request on other QoS flows (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: The QoS flow shall not pre-empt other QoS flow or, the QoS flow may pre-empt other QoS flows. NOTE: The Pre-emption Capability indicator applies to the allocation of resources for a QoS flow and as such it provides the trigger to the pre-emption procedures/processes of the gNB.

9.2.3.7 Pre-emption Vulnerability IE Semantics: Desc.: This IE indicates the vulnerability of the QoS flow to preemption of other QoS flows (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: The QoS flow shall not be pre-empted by other QoS flows or the QoS flow may be pre-empted by other QoS flows. NOTE: Pre-emption Vulnerability indicator applies for the entire duration of the QoS flow, unless modified and as such indicates whether the QoS flow is a target of the pre-emption procedures/processes of the gNB.

9.2.3.5 GBR QoS Flow Information IE Semantics: This IE shall be present for GBR QoS flows and is ignored otherwise. 9.2.3.6 GBR QoS Flow Information - Section Description: This IE indicates QoS Parameters for a GBR QoS Flow for downlink and uplink.

9.2.3.6 Maximum Flow Bit Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Maximum Bit Rate in DL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Maximum Flow Bit Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Maximum Bit Rate in UL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Guaranteed Flow Bit Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Guaranteed Bit Rate (provided that there is data to deliver) in DL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Guaranteed Flow Bit Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Guaranteed Bit Rate (provided that there is data to deliver). Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s
9.2.3.6 Notification Control IE Semantics: Notification control is specified in TS 23.501 [7]

9.2.3.6 Maximum Packet Loss Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum rate for lost packets that can be tolerated in the downlink direction. Maximum Packet Loss Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Loss Rate for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate IE Semantics: Ratio of lost packets per number of packets sent, expressed in tenth of percent.

9.2.3.6 Maximum Packet Loss Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum rate for lost packets that can be tolerated in the uplink direction. Maximum Packet Loss Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Loss Rate for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate IE Semantics: Ratio of lost packets per number of packets sent, expressed in tenth of percent.
9.2.3.5 Reflective QoS Attribute IE Semantics: Reflective QoS is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. This IE applies to Non-GBR bearers only and is ignored otherwise.

9.2.3.5 Additional QoS flow Information IE Semantics: If this IE is set to "more likely", this indicates that traffic for this QoS flow is likely to appear more often than traffic for other flows established for the PDU session. This IE may be present in case of Non-GBR flows only and is ignored otherwise.

9.2.3.5 QoS Monitoring Request IE Semantics: Indicates to measure UL, or DL, or both UL/DL delays for the associated QoS flow. 8.2.4 Retrieve UE Context 8.2.4.2 Successful Operation For each QoS flow in the RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT RESPONSE message, if the QoS Monitoring Request IE is included in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE in the PDU Session Resources To Be Setup List IE, the new NG-RAN node shall store this information, and, if supported, perform delay measurement and QoS monitoring, as specified in TS 23.501 [7].
│  │     ├─Data Forwarding and Offloading Info from source NG-RAN node

9.2.1.17 Data Forwarding and Offloading Info from source NG-RAN node - Section Description: This IE contains information from a source NG-RAN node regarding per QoS flow proposed data forwarding and offloading.
9.2.3.10 QoS Flow Identifier - Section Description: This IE identifies a QoS Flow within a PDU Session. Definition and use of the QoS Flow Identifier is specified in TS 23.501 [7].
9.2.3.34 DL Forwarding - Section Description: This element indicates a proposal for forwarding of downlink packets.
9.2.1.17 UL Forwarding IE Semantics: This IE shall be ignored. 9.2.3.90 UL Forwarding - Section Description: This element indicates a proposal for forwarding of uplink packets.
9.2.3.95 UL Forwarding Proposal - Section Description: This IE indicates a proposal for forwarding of uplink packets.
│  │     │  └─Source DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List

9.2.1.17 Source DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List IE Semantics: Usage of the DRB IDs indicated in the Source DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List IE is specified in TS 37.340 [8]. 9.2.1.15 DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List - Section Description: This IE contains a list of DRBs containing information about the mapped QoS flows.
9.2.3.33 DRB ID - Section Description: This IE contains the DRB ID.
9.2.3.10 QoS Flow Identifier - Section Description: This IE identifies a QoS Flow within a PDU Session. Definition and use of the QoS Flow Identifier is specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.79 QoS Flow Mapping Indication - Section Description: This IE is used to indicate whether only the uplink or the downlink of a QoS flow is mapped to a DRB. 9.2.3.79 QoS Flow Mapping Indication IE Semantics: This IE indicates whether only the uplink or the downlink QoS flow is mapped to the DRB

9.2.1.15 RLC Mode IE Semantics: Indicates the RLC mode for PDCP transfer between M-NG-RAN node and S-NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.28 RLC Mode - Section Description: The RLC Mode IE indicates the RLC Mode used for a DRB.

9.2.3.92 Common Network Instance - Section Description: This IE provides the common network instance to be used by the NG-RAN node when selecting a particular transport network resource as described in TS 23.501 [7] in a format common with 5GC.

9.2.1.13 RRC Context IE Semantics: Either includes the HandoverPreparationInformation message as defined in subclause 11.2.2 of TS 38.331[10], if the old and new serving NG-RAN nodes are gNBs, or the HandoverPreparationInformation message as defined in subclause 10.2.2 of TS 36.331 [14], if the old and new serving NG-RAN nodes are ng-eNBs.

9.2.3.53 Mobility Restriction List - Section Description: This IE defines roaming or access restrictions for subsequent mobility actions for which the NR-RAN provides information about the target of the mobility action towards the UE, e.g., handover, or for SCG selection during dual connectivity operation or for assigning proper RNAs. If the NG-RAN receives the Mobility Restriction List IE, it shall overwrite previously received restriction information. NG-RAN behaviour upon receiving this IE is specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).

9.2.3.53 Equivalent PLMNs IE Semantics: Allowed PLMNs in addition to Serving PLMN. This list corresponds to the list of “equivalent PLMNs” as defined in TS 24.501 [30]. This list is part of the roaming restriction information. Roaming restrictions apply to PLMNs other than the Serving PLMN and Equivalent PLMNs.

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.3.53 RAT Restrictions IE Semantics: This IE contains RAT restriction related information as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).

9.2.3.53 RAT Restriction Information IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a RAT. If a bit is set to "1", the respective RAT is restricted for the UE. If a bit is set to "0", the respective RAT is not restricted for the UE. This version of the specification does not use bits 3-7, the sending node shall set bits 3-7 to "0", the sender shall ignore bits 3-7.

9.2.3.53 Extended RAT Restriction Information IE Semantics: If this IE is included, the RAT Restriction Information IE is ignored. 9.2.3.99 Extended RAT Restriction Information - Section Description: This element provides RAT restrictions as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.99 Primary RAT Restriction IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a RAT. If a bit is set to "1", the respective RAT is restricted for the UE. If a bit is set to "0", the respective RAT is not restricted for the UE. Bits 3-7 reserved for future use. The Primary RAT is the RAT used in the access cell, or target cell.
BIT STRING { e-UTRA (0), nR (1), e-UTRA-unlicensed (2), nR-unlicensed (3)} (SIZE (8, …))

9.2.3.99 Secondary RAT Restriction IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a RAT. If a bit is set to "1", the respective RAT is restricted for the UE. If a bit is set to "0", the respective RAT is not restricted for the UE. Bits 4-7 reserved for future use. A Secondary RAT is a RAT used in any cell serving the UE excluding the PCell.
9.2.3.53 Forbidden Area Information IE Semantics: This IE contains Forbidden Area information as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.3.53 TAC IE Semantics: The TAC of the forbidden TAI. 9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.
9.2.3.53 Service Area Information IE Semantics: This IE contains Service Area Restriction information as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.3.53 TAC IE Semantics: The TAC of the allowed TAI. 9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.
9.2.3.53 TAC IE Semantics: The TAC of the not-allowed TAI. 9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.

9.2.3.53 Last E-UTRAN PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Indicates the E-UTRAN PLMN ID from where the UE formerly handed over to 5GS and which is preferred in case of subsequent mobility to EPS. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
│  │  ├─Core Network Type Restriction for serving PLMN
9.2.3.53 Core Network Type Restriction for serving PLMN IE Semantics: Indicates whether the UE is restricted to connect to EPC for the Serving PLMN as specified in TS 23.501 [7].
│  │  └─Core Network Type Restriction for Equivalent PLMNs

9.2.3.53 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Includes any of the Equivalent PLMNs listed in the Mobility Restriction List IE for which CN Type restriction applies as specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.3.53 Core Network Type Restriction IE Semantics: Indicates whether the UE is restricted to connect to EPC or to 5GC for this PLMN.

9.2.3.23 Index to RAT/Frequency Selection Priority - Section Description: The Index to RAT/Frequency Selection Priority IE is used to define local configuration for RRM strategies such as camp priorities and control of inter-RAT/inter-frequency mobility in RRC_CONNECTED, as specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 8.2.4 Retrieve UE Context 8.2.4.2 Successful Operation If the Index to RAT/Frequency Selection Priority IE is contained in the RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT RESPONSE message, the new NG-RAN node shall store this information and use it as defined in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.100 5GC Mobility Restriction List Container - Section Description: This IE contains the Mobility Restriction List IE specified in TS 38.413 [5] as received by the NG-RAN from the 5GC. 9.2.3.100 5GC Mobility Restriction List Container IE Semantics: The octets of the OCTET STRING are encoded according to the specifications of the Mobility Restriction List IE specified in TS 38.413 [5]. 8.2.4 Retrieve UE Context 8.2.4.2 Successful Operation If the 5GC Mobility Restriction List Container IE is included in the RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT RESPONSE message, the new NG-RAN node shall, if supported, store this information in the UE context and use it as specified in TS 38.300 [9].
9.2.3.55 Trace Activation - Section Description: This IE defines parameters related to a trace activation.

9.2.3.97 NG-RAN Trace ID - Section Description: This IE defines the NG-RAN Trace ID. 9.2.3.97 NG-RAN Trace ID IE Semantics: This IE is composed of the following: Trace Reference defined in TS 32.422 [23] (leftmost 6 octets, with PLMN information encoded as in 9.2.2.4), and Trace Recording Session Reference defined in TS 32.422 [23] (last 2 octets).

9.2.3.55 Interfaces To Trace IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents an NG-RAN node interface: first bit = NG-C, second bit = Xn-C, third bit = Uu, fourth bit = F1-C, fifth bit = E1: other bits reserved for future use. Value ‘1’ indicates ‘should be traced’. Value ‘0’ indicates ‘should not be traced’.
ENUMERATED (minimum, medium, maximum, MinimumWithoutVendorSpecificExtension, MediumWithoutVendorSpecificExtension, MaximumWithoutVendorSpecificExtension, …)
9.2.3.55 Trace Depth IE Semantics: Defined in TS 32.422 [23].
9.2.3.55 Trace Collection Entity IP Address IE Semantics: Defined in TS 32.422 [23] 9.2.3.29 Transport Layer Address - Section Description: This IE is defined to contain an IP address.

9.2.3.32 Masked IMEISV - Section Description: This information element contains the IMEISV value with a mask, to identify a terminal model without identifying an individual Mobile Equipment. 9.2.3.32 Masked IMEISV IE Semantics: Coded as the International Mobile station Equipment Identity and Software Version Number (IMEISV) defined in TS 23.003 [22] with the last 4 digits of the SNR masked by setting the corresponding bits to 1.

9.1.1.9 Location Reporting Information IE Semantics: Includes the necessary parameters for location reporting. 9.2.3.47 Location Reporting Information - Section Description: This information element indicates how the location information should be reported. 8.2.4 Retrieve UE Context 8.2.4.2 Successful Operation If the Location Reporting Information IE is included in the RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT RESPONSE message, then the new NG-RAN node should initiate the requested location reporting functionality as defined in TS 38.413 [5].
ENUMERATED ( report upon change of serving cell, report UE moving presence into or out of the Area of Interest, …)
9.2.3.48 Area of Interest Information - Section Description: This IE contains indicates the Area of Interest information, which may contain multiple Areas of Interest, as specified in TS 23.502 [13].
│     ├─List of TAIs in Area of Interest

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.
│     ├─List of Cells in Area of Interest
9.2.3.48 List of Cells in Area of Interest IE Semantics: This IE may need to be refined with SA2.

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.9 NG-RAN Cell Identity - Section Description: This IE contains either an NR or an E-UTRA Cell Identity.
9.2.2.9 NR Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE correspond to the gNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.1).
9.2.2.9 E-UTRA Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE correspond to the ng-eNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.8).
│     ├─List of Global NG-RAN Nodes in Area of Interest
│     │  └─Global NG-RAN Node in Area of Interest Item
9.2.2.3 Global NG-RAN Node ID - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an NG-RAN node (see TS 38.300 [9]).
9.2.2.1 Global gNB ID - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify a gNB (see TS 38.300 [9]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.1 gNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE contained in the NR CGI IE of each cell served by the gNB.
9.2.2.2 Global ng-eNB ID - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an ng-eNB (see TS 38.300 [9]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.2 Macro ng-eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 20 leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE contained in the E-UTRA CGI IE of each cell served by the ng-eNB.
9.2.2.2 Short Macro ng-eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 18 leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE contained in the E-UTRA CGI IE of each cell served by the ng-eNB.
9.2.2.2 Long Macro ng-eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 21 leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE contained in the E-UTRA CGI IE of each cell served by the ng-eNB.

9.2.3.58 Request Reporting Reference ID - Section Description: This IE contains the Request Reporting Reference ID and is used for UE presence in Area of Interest reporting as specified in TS 23.502 [13].

9.2.3.3 Criticality Diagnostics - Section Description: The Criticality Diagnostics IE is sent by the NG-RAN node when parts of a received message have not been comprehended or were missing, or if the message contained logical errors. When applicable, it contains information about which IEs were not comprehended or were missing.

9.2.3.3 Procedure Code IE Semantics: Procedure Code is to be used if Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure, and not within the response message of the same procedure that caused the error.
ENUMERATED (initiating message, successful outcome, unsuccessful outcome)
9.2.3.3 Triggering Message IE Semantics: The Triggering Message is used only if the Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure.
9.2.3.3 Procedure Criticality IE Semantics: This Procedure Criticality is used for reporting the Criticality of the Triggering message (Procedure).
9.2.3.3 IE Criticality IE Semantics: The IE Criticality is used for reporting the criticality of the triggering IE. The value "ignore" is not applicable.
9.2.3.3 IE ID IE Semantics: The IE ID of the not understood or missing IE

section_list.name: RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT FAILURE
aoa:
This message is sent by the old NG-RAN node to inform the new NG-RAN node that the Retrieve UE Context procedure has failed.
Direction: old NG-RAN node ? new NG-RAN node.
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)
├─New NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID reference

9.1.1.10 New NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID reference IE Semantics: Allocated at the new NG-RAN node 9.2.3.16 NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID - Section Description: The NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID uniquely identifies a UE over the Xn interface within the NG-RAN node. The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.
├─Old NG-RAN node To New NG-RAN node Resume Container

9.1.1.10 Old NG-RAN node To New NG-RAN node Resume Container IE Semantics: Includes either the RRCRelease message as defined in TS 38.331 [10], or the RRCConnectionRelease message as defined in TS 36.331 [14], encapsulated in a PDCP-C PDU. 8.2.4 Retrieve UE Context 8.2.4.3 Unsuccessful Operation If the Old NG-RAN node To New NG-RAN node Resume Container IE is included in the RETRIEVE UE CONTEXT FAILURE message, the new NG-RAN node should transparently forward the content of this IE to the UE as described in TS 38.300 [9].
9.2.3.2 Cause - Section Description: The purpose of the Cause IE is to indicate the reason for a particular event for the XnAP protocol.

ENUMERATED ( Cell not Available, Handover Desirable for Radio Reasons, Handover Target not Allowed, Invalid AMF Set ID, No Radio Resources Available in Target Cell, Partial Handover, Reduce Load in Serving Cell, Resource Optimisation Handover, Time Critical Handover, TXnRELOCoverall Expiry, TXnRELOCprep Expiry, Unknown GUAMI ID, Unknown Local NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, Inconsistent Remote NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, Encryption And/Or Integrity Protection Algorithms Not Supported, Protection Algorithms Not Supported, Multiple PDU Session ID Instances, Unknown PDU Session ID, Unknown QoS Flow ID, Multiple QoS Flow ID Instances, Switch Off Ongoing, Not supported 5QI value, TXnDCoverall Expiry, TXnDCprep Expiry, Action Desirable for Radio Reasons, Reduce Load, Resource Optimisation, Time Critical action, Target not Allowed, No Radio Resources Available, Invalid QoS combination, Encryption Algorithms Not Supported, Procedure cancelled, RRM purpose, Improve User Bit Rate, User Inactivity, Radio Connection With UE Lost, Failure in the Radio Interface Procedure, Bearer Option not Supported, UP integrity protection not possible, UP confidentiality protection not possible, Resources not available for the slice (s), UE Maximum integrity protected data rate reason, CP Integrity Protection Failure, UP Integrity Protection Failure, Slice (s) not supported by NG-RAN, MN Mobility, SN Mobility, Count reaches max value, Unknown Old NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID, PDCP Overload, DRB ID not available, Unspecified, …, UE Context ID not known, Non-relocation of context)

ENUMERATED (Transfer Syntax Error, Abstract Syntax Error (Reject), Abstract Syntax Error (Ignore and Notify), Message not Compatible with Receiver State, Semantic Error, Abstract Syntax Error (Falsely Constructed Message), Unspecified, …)
ENUMERATED (Control Processing Overload, Hardware Failure, O&M Intervention, Not enough User Plane Processing Resources, Unspecified, …)

9.2.3.3 Criticality Diagnostics - Section Description: The Criticality Diagnostics IE is sent by the NG-RAN node when parts of a received message have not been comprehended or were missing, or if the message contained logical errors. When applicable, it contains information about which IEs were not comprehended or were missing.

9.2.3.3 Procedure Code IE Semantics: Procedure Code is to be used if Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure, and not within the response message of the same procedure that caused the error.
ENUMERATED (initiating message, successful outcome, unsuccessful outcome)
9.2.3.3 Triggering Message IE Semantics: The Triggering Message is used only if the Criticality Diagnostics is part of Error Indication procedure.
9.2.3.3 Procedure Criticality IE Semantics: This Procedure Criticality is used for reporting the Criticality of the Triggering message (Procedure).
9.2.3.3 IE Criticality IE Semantics: The IE Criticality is used for reporting the criticality of the triggering IE. The value "ignore" is not applicable.
9.2.3.3 IE ID IE Semantics: The IE ID of the not understood or missing IE

section_list.name: XN-U ADDRESS INDICATION
aoa:
This message is either sent by the new NG-RAN node to transfer data forwarding information to the old NG-RAN node, or by the M-NG-RAN node to provide either data forwarding or Xn-U bearer address information for SN terminated bearers to the S-NG-RAN node.
Direction: new NG-RAN node ? old NG-RAN node, M-NG-RAN node ? S-NG-RAN node.
9.2.3.1 Message Type - Section Description: The Message Type IE uniquely identifies the message being sent. It is mandatory for all messages.
CHOICE (Initiating Message, Successful Outcome, Unsuccessful Outcome, …)

The use of this IE is defined in TS 38.401 [2]. NOTE: If Xn-C signalling transport is shared among multiple interface instances, the value of the NG-RAN node UE XnAP ID is allocated so that it can be associated with the corresponding Xn-C interface instance.
