9.2.1.1 Source DL NG-U TNL Information IE Semantics: Indicates the possibility to keep the NG-U GTP-U tunnel termination point at the target NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.30 UP Transport Layer Information - Section Description: This element is used to provide the transport layer information associated with NG or Xn user plane transport. In this release it corresponds to an IP adress and a GTP Tunnel Endpoint Identifier.

9.2.3.30 Transport Layer Address IE Semantics: The Transport Layer Address is specified in TS 38.424 [19] and TS 38.414 [20]. 9.2.3.29 Transport Layer Address - Section Description: This IE is defined to contain an IP address.
9.2.3.30 GTP-TEID IE Semantics: The Tunnel Endpoint Identifier (TEID) is specified in TS 29.281 [18]

9.2.3.52 Security Indication - Section Description: This IE contains the user plane integrity protection indication and confidentiality protection indication which indicates the requirements on UP integrity protection and ciphering for the corresponding PDU session, respectively. Additionally, this IE contains the maximum integrity protected data rate values (UL and DL) per UE for integrity protected DRBs.
9.2.3.52 Integrity Protection Indication IE Semantics: Indicates whether UP integrity protection shall apply, should apply, or shall not apply for the concerned PDU session.
9.2.3.52 Confidentiality Protection Indication IE Semantics: Indicates whether UP ciphering shall apply, should apply, or shall not apply for the concerned PDU session.

9.2.3.52 - Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate IE - ifIntegrityProtectionrequiredorpreferred: This IE shall be present if the Integrity Protection IE within the Security Indication IE is present and set to “required” or “preferred”. 9.2.3.52 Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate IE Semantics: If present, this IE contains the values received from the CN for the overall UE capability. This IE may be ignored by the SN in the case of dual connectivity. 9.2.3.73 Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the maximum aggregate data rate for integrity protected DRBs for a UE as defined in TS 38.300 [9].

9.2.3.73 Maximum IP Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum aggregate rate for integrity protected DRBs supported by the UE in UL. If the Maximum IP Rate Downlink IE is absent, this IE applies to both UL and DL. 9.2.3.89 Maximum IP Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the maximum aggregate data rate for integrity protected DRBs for a UE as defined in TS 38.300 [9]. 9.2.3.89 Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate IE Semantics: Defines the upper bound of the aggregate data rate of user plane integrity protected data.

9.2.3.73 Maximum IP Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum aggregate rate for integrity protected DRBs supported by the UE in the DL. 9.2.3.89 Maximum IP Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the maximum aggregate data rate for integrity protected DRBs for a UE as defined in TS 38.300 [9]. 9.2.3.89 Maximum Integrity Protected Data Rate IE Semantics: Defines the upper bound of the aggregate data rate of user plane integrity protected data.
9.2.3.19 PDU Session Type - Section Description: This IE defines the PDU Session Type as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.1.1 Network Instance IE Semantics: This IE is ignored if the Common Network Instance IE is present. 9.2.3.85 Network Instance - Section Description: This IE provides the network instance to be used by the NG-RAN node when selecting a particular transport network resource as described in TS 23.501 [7].
9.2.3.10 QoS Flow Identifier - Section Description: This IE identifies a QoS Flow within a PDU Session. Definition and use of the QoS Flow Identifier is specified in TS 23.501 [7].
9.2.3.5 QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters - Section Description: This IE defines the QoS Parameters to be applied to a QoS flow.
9.2.3.8 Non dynamic 5QI Descriptor - Section Description: This IE defines QoS characteristics for a standardized or pre-configured 5QI for downlink and uplink.
9.2.3.8 5QI IE Semantics: This IE contains the standardized or pre-configured 5QI as specified in TS 23.501 [7}

9.2.3.8 Priority Level IE Semantics: Priority level is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. When included, it overrides standardized or pre-configured value. 9.2.3.62 Priority Level - Section Description: This IE indicates the Priority Level for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.62 Priority Level IE Semantics: Values ordered in decreasing order of priority, i.e. with 1 as the highest priority and 127 as the lowest priority.

9.2.3.8 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Averaging window is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. When included, it overrides standardized or pre-configured value. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window - Section Description: This IE indicates the Averaging Window for a QoS flow and applies to GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Unit: ms.

9.2.3.8 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Maximum Data Burst Volume is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. When included, it overrides standardized or pre-configured value. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume - Section Description: This IE indicates the Maximum Data Burst Volume for a QoS flow and applies to delay critical GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Unit: byte,
9.2.3.9 Dynamic 5QI Descriptor - Section Description: This IE defines the QoS characteristics for a non-standardized or not pre-configured 5QI for downlink and uplink.

9.2.3.9 Priority Level IE Semantics: Priority level is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.62 Priority Level - Section Description: This IE indicates the Priority Level for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.62 Priority Level IE Semantics: Values ordered in decreasing order of priority, i.e. with 1 as the highest priority and 127 as the lowest priority.

9.2.3.9 Packet Delay Budget IE Semantics: Packet Delay Budget is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.12 Packet Delay Budget - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Delay Budget for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.12 Packet Delay Budget IE Semantics: Upper bound value for the delay that a packet may experience expressed in units of 0.5ms.
9.2.3.9 Packet Error Rate IE Semantics: Packet Error Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.13 Packet Error Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Error Rate for a QoS flow.
9.2.3.13 Scalar IE Semantics: The packet error rate is expressed as Scalar * 10-k, whereas k is the Exponent.
9.2.3.9 5QI IE Semantics: This IE contains the dynamically assigned 5QI as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.9 - Delay Critical IE - ifGBRflow: This IE shall be present if the GBR QoS Flow Information IE is present in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE. 9.2.3.9 Delay Critical IE Semantics: This IE indicates whether the GBR QoS flow is delay critical as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.9 - Averaging Window IE - ifGBRflow: This IE shall be present if the GBR QoS Flow Information IE is present in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE. 9.2.3.9 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Averaging window is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window - Section Description: This IE indicates the Averaging Window for a QoS flow and applies to GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Unit: ms.

9.2.3.9 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Maximum Data Burst Volume is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. This IE shall be included if the Delay Critical IE is set to "delay critical" and is be ignored otherwise. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume - Section Description: This IE indicates the Maximum Data Burst Volume for a QoS flow and applies to delay critical GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Unit: byte,
9.2.3.7 Allocation and Retention Priority - Section Description: This IE specifies the relative importance compared to other QoS flows for allocation and retention of the NR RAN resource.

9.2.3.7 Priority Level IE Semantics: Desc.: This defines the relative importance of a resource request. (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: Values between 1 and 15 are ordered in decreasing order of priority, i.e., 1 is the highest and 15 is the lowest.
ENUMERATED (shall not trigger pre-emption, may trigger pre-emption, ...)

9.2.3.7 Pre-emption Capability IE Semantics: Desc.: This IE indicates the pre-emption capability of the request on other QoS flows (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: The QoS flow shall not pre-empt other QoS flow or, the QoS flow may pre-empt other QoS flows. NOTE: The Pre-emption Capability indicator applies to the allocation of resources for a QoS flow and as such it provides the trigger to the pre-emption procedures/processes of the gNB.

9.2.3.7 Pre-emption Vulnerability IE Semantics: Desc.: This IE indicates the vulnerability of the QoS flow to preemption of other QoS flows (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: The QoS flow shall not be pre-empted by other QoS flows or the QoS flow may be pre-empted by other QoS flows. NOTE: Pre-emption Vulnerability indicator applies for the entire duration of the QoS flow, unless modified and as such indicates whether the QoS flow is a target of the pre-emption procedures/processes of the gNB.

9.2.3.5 GBR QoS Flow Information IE Semantics: This IE shall be present for GBR QoS flows and is ignored otherwise. 9.2.3.6 GBR QoS Flow Information - Section Description: This IE indicates QoS Parameters for a GBR QoS Flow for downlink and uplink.

9.2.3.6 Maximum Flow Bit Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Maximum Bit Rate in DL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Maximum Flow Bit Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Maximum Bit Rate in UL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Guaranteed Flow Bit Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Guaranteed Bit Rate (provided that there is data to deliver) in DL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Guaranteed Flow Bit Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Guaranteed Bit Rate (provided that there is data to deliver). Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s
9.2.3.6 Notification Control IE Semantics: Notification control is specified in TS 23.501 [7]

9.2.3.6 Maximum Packet Loss Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum rate for lost packets that can be tolerated in the downlink direction. Maximum Packet Loss Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Loss Rate for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate IE Semantics: Ratio of lost packets per number of packets sent, expressed in tenth of percent.

9.2.3.6 Maximum Packet Loss Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum rate for lost packets that can be tolerated in the uplink direction. Maximum Packet Loss Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Loss Rate for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate IE Semantics: Ratio of lost packets per number of packets sent, expressed in tenth of percent.
9.2.3.5 Reflective QoS Attribute IE Semantics: Reflective QoS is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. This IE applies to Non-GBR bearers only and is ignored otherwise.

9.2.3.5 Additional QoS flow Information IE Semantics: If this IE is set to "more likely", this indicates that traffic for this QoS flow is likely to appear more often than traffic for other flows established for the PDU session. This IE may be present in case of Non-GBR flows only and is ignored otherwise.
9.2.3.5 QoS Monitoring Request IE Semantics: Indicates to measure UL, or DL, or both UL/DL delays for the associated QoS flow.
│     ├─Data Forwarding and Offloading Info from source NG-RAN node

9.2.1.17 Data Forwarding and Offloading Info from source NG-RAN node - Section Description: This IE contains information from a source NG-RAN node regarding per QoS flow proposed data forwarding and offloading.
9.2.3.10 QoS Flow Identifier - Section Description: This IE identifies a QoS Flow within a PDU Session. Definition and use of the QoS Flow Identifier is specified in TS 23.501 [7].
9.2.3.34 DL Forwarding - Section Description: This element indicates a proposal for forwarding of downlink packets.
9.2.1.17 UL Forwarding IE Semantics: This IE shall be ignored. 9.2.3.90 UL Forwarding - Section Description: This element indicates a proposal for forwarding of uplink packets.
9.2.3.95 UL Forwarding Proposal - Section Description: This IE indicates a proposal for forwarding of uplink packets.
│     │  └─Source DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List

9.2.1.17 Source DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List IE Semantics: Usage of the DRB IDs indicated in the Source DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List IE is specified in TS 37.340 [8]. 9.2.1.15 DRB to QoS Flow Mapping List - Section Description: This IE contains a list of DRBs containing information about the mapped QoS flows.
9.2.3.33 DRB ID - Section Description: This IE contains the DRB ID.
9.2.3.10 QoS Flow Identifier - Section Description: This IE identifies a QoS Flow within a PDU Session. Definition and use of the QoS Flow Identifier is specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.79 QoS Flow Mapping Indication - Section Description: This IE is used to indicate whether only the uplink or the downlink of a QoS flow is mapped to a DRB. 9.2.3.79 QoS Flow Mapping Indication IE Semantics: This IE indicates whether only the uplink or the downlink QoS flow is mapped to the DRB

9.2.1.15 RLC Mode IE Semantics: Indicates the RLC mode for PDCP transfer between M-NG-RAN node and S-NG-RAN node. 9.2.3.28 RLC Mode - Section Description: The RLC Mode IE indicates the RLC Mode used for a DRB.

9.2.3.92 Common Network Instance - Section Description: This IE provides the common network instance to be used by the NG-RAN node when selecting a particular transport network resource as described in TS 23.501 [7] in a format common with 5GC.

9.2.1.13 RRC Context IE Semantics: Either includes the HandoverPreparationInformation message as defined in subclause 11.2.2 of TS 38.331[10], if the old and new serving NG-RAN nodes are gNBs, or the HandoverPreparationInformation message as defined in subclause 10.2.2 of TS 36.331 [14], if the old and new serving NG-RAN nodes are ng-eNBs.

9.2.3.53 Mobility Restriction List - Section Description: This IE defines roaming or access restrictions for subsequent mobility actions for which the NR-RAN provides information about the target of the mobility action towards the UE, e.g., handover, or for SCG selection during dual connectivity operation or for assigning proper RNAs. If the NG-RAN receives the Mobility Restriction List IE, it shall overwrite previously received restriction information. NG-RAN behaviour upon receiving this IE is specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).

9.2.3.53 Equivalent PLMNs IE Semantics: Allowed PLMNs in addition to Serving PLMN. This list corresponds to the list of “equivalent PLMNs” as defined in TS 24.501 [30]. This list is part of the roaming restriction information. Roaming restrictions apply to PLMNs other than the Serving PLMN and Equivalent PLMNs.

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.3.53 RAT Restrictions IE Semantics: This IE contains RAT restriction related information as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).

9.2.3.53 RAT Restriction Information IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a RAT. If a bit is set to "1", the respective RAT is restricted for the UE. If a bit is set to "0", the respective RAT is not restricted for the UE. This version of the specification does not use bits 3-7, the sending node shall set bits 3-7 to "0", the sender shall ignore bits 3-7.

9.2.3.53 Extended RAT Restriction Information IE Semantics: If this IE is included, the RAT Restriction Information IE is ignored. 9.2.3.99 Extended RAT Restriction Information - Section Description: This element provides RAT restrictions as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.99 Primary RAT Restriction IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a RAT. If a bit is set to "1", the respective RAT is restricted for the UE. If a bit is set to "0", the respective RAT is not restricted for the UE. Bits 3-7 reserved for future use. The Primary RAT is the RAT used in the access cell, or target cell.
BIT STRING { e-UTRA (0), nR (1), e-UTRA-unlicensed (2), nR-unlicensed (3)} (SIZE (8, …))

9.2.3.99 Secondary RAT Restriction IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a RAT. If a bit is set to "1", the respective RAT is restricted for the UE. If a bit is set to "0", the respective RAT is not restricted for the UE. Bits 4-7 reserved for future use. A Secondary RAT is a RAT used in any cell serving the UE excluding the PCell.
9.2.3.53 Forbidden Area Information IE Semantics: This IE contains Forbidden Area information as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.3.53 TAC IE Semantics: The TAC of the forbidden TAI. 9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.
9.2.3.53 Service Area Information IE Semantics: This IE contains Service Area Restriction information as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.3.53 TAC IE Semantics: The TAC of the allowed TAI. 9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.
9.2.3.53 TAC IE Semantics: The TAC of the not-allowed TAI. 9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.

9.2.3.53 Last E-UTRAN PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Indicates the E-UTRAN PLMN ID from where the UE formerly handed over to 5GS and which is preferred in case of subsequent mobility to EPS. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).

9.2.3.53 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Includes any of the Equivalent PLMNs listed in the Mobility Restriction List IE for which CN Type restriction applies as specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).

9.2.3.23 Index to RAT/Frequency Selection Priority - Section Description: The Index to RAT/Frequency Selection Priority IE is used to define local configuration for RRM strategies such as camp priorities and control of inter-RAT/inter-frequency mobility in RRC_CONNECTED, as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.100 5GC Mobility Restriction List Container - Section Description: This IE contains the Mobility Restriction List IE specified in TS 38.413 [5] as received by the NG-RAN from the 5GC. 9.2.3.100 5GC Mobility Restriction List Container IE Semantics: The octets of the OCTET STRING are encoded according to the specifications of the Mobility Restriction List IE specified in TS 38.413 [5].

section_list.name: DRBs Subject To Status Transfer List
aoa: DRBs Subject To Status Transfer Item
9.2.1.14 DRBs Subject To Status Transfer Item IE Semantics: This IE contains a list of DRBs containing information about PDCP PDU transfer status.
9.2.3.33 DRB ID - Section Description: This IE contains the DRB ID.

9.2.1.14 Receive Status Of PDCP SDU IE Semantics: The IE is used in case of 12-bit long PDCP-SN. The first bit indicates the status of the SDU after the First Missing UL PDCP SDU. The Nth bit indicates the status of the UL PDCP SDU in position (N + First Missing SDU Number) modulo (1 + the maximum value of the PDCP-SN). 0: PDCP SDU has not been received. 1: PDCP SDU has been received correctly.

9.2.1.14 UL COUNT Value IE Semantics: PDCP-SN and Hyper Frame Number of the first missing UL SDU in case of 12-bit long PDCP-SN 9.2.3.36 COUNT Value for PDCP SN Length 12 - Section Description: This information element indicates the 12-bit long PDCP sequence number and the corresponding 20 bits long Hyper Frame Number.

9.2.1.14 Receive Status Of PDCP SDU IE Semantics: The IE is used in case of 18-bit long PDCP-SN. The first bit indicates the status of the SDU after the First Missing UL PDCP SDU. The Nth bit indicates the status of the UL PDCP SDU in position (N + First Missing SDU Number) modulo (1 + the maximum value of the PDCP-SN). 0: PDCP SDU has not been received. 1: PDCP SDU has been received correctly.

9.2.1.14 UL COUNT Value IE Semantics: PDCP-SN and Hyper Frame Number of the first missing UL SDU in case of 18-bit long PDCP-SN 9.2.3.37 COUNT Value for PDCP SN Length 18 - Section Description: This information element indicates the 18-bit long PDCP sequence number and the corresponding 14 bits long Hyper Frame Number.

9.2.1.14 DL COUNT Value IE Semantics: PDCP-SN and Hyper Frame Number that the target NG-RAN node (handover) or the NG-RAN node to which the DRB context is transferred (dual connectivity) should assign for the next DL SDU not having an SN yet in case of 12-bit long PDCP-SN 9.2.3.36 COUNT Value for PDCP SN Length 12 - Section Description: This information element indicates the 12-bit long PDCP sequence number and the corresponding 20 bits long Hyper Frame Number.

9.2.1.14 DL COUNT Value IE Semantics: PDCP-SN and Hyper Frame Number that the target NG-RAN node (handover) or the NG-RAN node to which the DRB context is transferred (dual connectivity) should assign for the next DL SDU not having an SN yet in case of 18-bit long PDCP-SN 9.2.3.37 COUNT Value for PDCP SN Length 18 - Section Description: This information element indicates the 18-bit long PDCP sequence number and the corresponding 14 bits long Hyper Frame Number.

ENUMERATED (shall not trigger pre-emption, may trigger pre-emption, ...)

9.2.3.7 Pre-emption Capability IE Semantics: Desc.: This IE indicates the pre-emption capability of the request on other QoS flows (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: The QoS flow shall not pre-empt other QoS flow or, the QoS flow may pre-empt other QoS flows. NOTE: The Pre-emption Capability indicator applies to the allocation of resources for a QoS flow and as such it provides the trigger to the pre-emption procedures/processes of the gNB.

9.2.3.7 Pre-emption Vulnerability IE Semantics: Desc.: This IE indicates the vulnerability of the QoS flow to preemption of other QoS flows (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: The QoS flow shall not be pre-empted by other QoS flows or the QoS flow may be pre-empted by other QoS flows. NOTE: Pre-emption Vulnerability indicator applies for the entire duration of the QoS flow, unless modified and as such indicates whether the QoS flow is a target of the pre-emption procedures/processes of the gNB.

9.2.3.9 Packet Delay Budget IE Semantics: Packet Delay Budget is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.12 Packet Delay Budget - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Delay Budget for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.12 Packet Delay Budget IE Semantics: Upper bound value for the delay that a packet may experience expressed in units of 0.5ms.
9.2.3.9 Packet Error Rate IE Semantics: Packet Error Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.13 Packet Error Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Error Rate for a QoS flow.
9.2.3.13 Scalar IE Semantics: The packet error rate is expressed as Scalar * 10-k, whereas k is the Exponent.
9.2.3.9 5QI IE Semantics: This IE contains the dynamically assigned 5QI as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.9 - Delay Critical IE - ifGBRflow: This IE shall be present if the GBR QoS Flow Information IE is present in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE. 9.2.3.9 Delay Critical IE Semantics: This IE indicates whether the GBR QoS flow is delay critical as specified in TS 23.501 [7].

9.2.3.9 - Averaging Window IE - ifGBRflow: This IE shall be present if the GBR QoS Flow Information IE is present in the QoS Flow Level QoS Parameters IE. 9.2.3.9 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Averaging window is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window - Section Description: This IE indicates the Averaging Window for a QoS flow and applies to GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.14 Averaging Window IE Semantics: Unit: ms.

9.2.3.9 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Maximum Data Burst Volume is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. This IE shall be included if the Delay Critical IE is set to "delay critical" and is be ignored otherwise. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume - Section Description: This IE indicates the Maximum Data Burst Volume for a QoS flow and applies to delay critical GBR QoS flows only. 9.2.3.15 Maximum Data Burst Volume IE Semantics: Unit: byte,
9.2.3.7 Allocation and Retention Priority - Section Description: This IE specifies the relative importance compared to other QoS flows for allocation and retention of the NR RAN resource.

9.2.3.7 Priority Level IE Semantics: Desc.: This defines the relative importance of a resource request. (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: Values between 1 and 15 are ordered in decreasing order of priority, i.e., 1 is the highest and 15 is the lowest.
ENUMERATED (shall not trigger pre-emption, may trigger pre-emption, ...)

9.2.3.7 Pre-emption Capability IE Semantics: Desc.: This IE indicates the pre-emption capability of the request on other QoS flows (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: The QoS flow shall not pre-empt other QoS flow or, the QoS flow may pre-empt other QoS flows. NOTE: The Pre-emption Capability indicator applies to the allocation of resources for a QoS flow and as such it provides the trigger to the pre-emption procedures/processes of the gNB.

9.2.3.7 Pre-emption Vulnerability IE Semantics: Desc.: This IE indicates the vulnerability of the QoS flow to preemption of other QoS flows (see TS 23.501 [7]). Usage: The QoS flow shall not be pre-empted by other QoS flows or the QoS flow may be pre-empted by other QoS flows. NOTE: Pre-emption Vulnerability indicator applies for the entire duration of the QoS flow, unless modified and as such indicates whether the QoS flow is a target of the pre-emption procedures/processes of the gNB.

9.2.3.5 GBR QoS Flow Information IE Semantics: This IE shall be present for GBR QoS flows and is ignored otherwise. 9.2.3.6 GBR QoS Flow Information - Section Description: This IE indicates QoS Parameters for a GBR QoS Flow for downlink and uplink.

9.2.3.6 Maximum Flow Bit Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Maximum Bit Rate in DL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Maximum Flow Bit Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Maximum Bit Rate in UL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Guaranteed Flow Bit Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Guaranteed Bit Rate (provided that there is data to deliver) in DL. Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s

9.2.3.6 Guaranteed Flow Bit Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Guaranteed Bit Rate (provided that there is data to deliver). Flow Bit Rates are specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the number of bits delivered by NG-RAN in UL or to NG-RAN in DL within a period of time, divided by the duration of the period. It is used, for example, to indicate the maximum or guaranteed bit rate for a GBR QoS flow, or an aggregate maximum bit rate. 9.2.3.4 Bit Rate IE Semantics: The unit is: bit/s
9.2.3.6 Notification Control IE Semantics: Notification control is specified in TS 23.501 [7]

9.2.3.6 Maximum Packet Loss Rate Downlink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum rate for lost packets that can be tolerated in the downlink direction. Maximum Packet Loss Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Loss Rate for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate IE Semantics: Ratio of lost packets per number of packets sent, expressed in tenth of percent.

9.2.3.6 Maximum Packet Loss Rate Uplink IE Semantics: Indicates the maximum rate for lost packets that can be tolerated in the uplink direction. Maximum Packet Loss Rate is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate - Section Description: This IE indicates the Packet Loss Rate for a QoS flow. 9.2.3.11 Packet Loss Rate IE Semantics: Ratio of lost packets per number of packets sent, expressed in tenth of percent.
9.2.3.5 Reflective QoS Attribute IE Semantics: Reflective QoS is specified in TS 23.501 [7]. This IE applies to Non-GBR bearers only and is ignored otherwise.

9.2.3.5 Additional QoS flow Information IE Semantics: If this IE is set to "more likely", this indicates that traffic for this QoS flow is likely to appear more often than traffic for other flows established for the PDU session. This IE may be present in case of Non-GBR flows only and is ignored otherwise.
9.2.3.5 QoS Monitoring Request IE Semantics: Indicates to measure UL, or DL, or both UL/DL delays for the associated QoS flow.

section_list.name: NG-RAN Node and Cell Configuration related IE definitions
Global gNB ID
aoa: This IE is used to globally identify a gNB (see TS 38.300 [9]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.1 gNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE contained in the NR CGI IE of each cell served by the gNB.

section_list.name: Global ng-eNB ID
aoa: This IE is used to globally identify an ng-eNB (see TS 38.300 [9]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.2 Macro ng-eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 20 leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE contained in the E-UTRA CGI IE of each cell served by the ng-eNB.
9.2.2.2 Short Macro ng-eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 18 leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE contained in the E-UTRA CGI IE of each cell served by the ng-eNB.
9.2.2.2 Long Macro ng-eNB ID IE Semantics: Equal to the 21 leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE contained in the E-UTRA CGI IE of each cell served by the ng-eNB.

Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).

9.2.2.40 Number of DL Symbols IE Semantics: Number of consecutive DL symbols at the beginning of the slot identified by Slot Index. If extended cyclic prefix is used, the maximum value is 11.
9.2.2.40 Number of UL Symbols IE Semantics: Number of consecutive UL symbols in the end of the slot identified by Slot Index. If extended cyclic prefix is used, the maximum value is 11.

9.2.2.24 E-UTRA Multiband Info List - Section Description: The E-UTRA Multiband Info List IE contains the additional frequency band indicators that an E-UTRA cell belongs to listed in decreasing order of preference and corresponds to the MultiBandInfoList specified in TS 36.331 [14].

9.2.2.12 Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication IE Semantics: This IE indicates which E-UTRA control/reference signal resources are protected and are not subject to E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination. 9.2.2.29 Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication - Section Description: This IE indicates the resources allocated for E-UTRA DL and UL reference and control signals (hereby referred to as protected resources). This information is used in the process of E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination.
9.2.2.29 Activation SFN IE Semantics: Indicates from which SFN of the receiving node the resource allocation is valid.

9.2.2.29 Protected Resource List IE Semantics: The protected resource pattern is continuously repeated, and it is valid until stated otherwise or until replaced by a new pattern. The pattern does not apply in reserved subframes.
9.2.2.29 Protected Resource List Item IE Semantics: Each item describes one transmission pattern. A pattern may comprise several control signals.
9.2.2.29 Resource Type IE Semantics: Indicates whether the protected resource is E-UTRA DL non-CRS, E-UTRA CRS or E-UTRA UL.

9.2.2.29 Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint IE Semantics: The bitmap of REs occupied by the protected signal within one PRB. Each position in the bitmap represents an RE in one PRB; value “0” indicates "resource not protected", value “1” indicates "resource protected ". The first bit of the string corresponds to the RE with the smallest time and frequency index in the PRB, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. The length of the bit string equals the product of  and the length of PRB in time dimension, measured in REs.  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The intra-PRB pattern consisting of all “1”s is equivalent to PRB-level granularity.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Frequency Pattern IE Semantics: The bit string indicates in which PRBs inside carrier bandwidth the Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint applies. How often in time dimension this frequency pattern applies, depends on time periodicity of Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint. The first bit of the bit string corresponds to the PRB occupying the lowest subcarrier frequencies of the carrier bandwidth, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. Each position in the string represents a PRB; value “0” indicates " Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint does not appear in PRB", value “1” indicates "Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint appears in PRB". The length of the bit string equals the number of PRBs in the carrier bandwidth.
9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Time Pattern IE Semantics: The description of time periodicity of the Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Time-periodicity IE Semantics: Periodicity with which the periodic Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint repeats in time-dimension (1= every PRB (i.e. slot), 2=every other PRB (i.e. slot) etc.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Start Time IE Semantics: The time-position of the PRB inside the frame in which the periodic Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint appears for the first time. The value “1” corresponds to the receiving node’s slot 0 in subframe 0 in the receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN.
9.2.2.29 MBSFN Control Region Length IE Semantics: Length of control region in MBSFN subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.
9.2.2.29 PDCCH Region Length IE Semantics: Length of PDCCH region in regular subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.

section_list.name: Neighbour Information E-UTRA
aoa: 9.2.2.14 E-UTRA Neighbour Information E-UTRA IE Semantics: This IE contains cell configuration information of E-UTRA cells that a neighbour NG-RAN node may need to properly operate its own served cells.
9.2.2.14 E-UTRA PCI IE Semantics: E-UTRA Physical Cell Identifier of the neighbour cell
9.2.2.8 E-UTRA CGI - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an E-UTRA cell (see TS 36.300 [12]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.8 E-UTRA Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE correspond to the ng-eNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.2).

9.2.2.14 EARFCN IE Semantics: DL EARFCN for FDD or EARFCN for TDD 9.2.2.21 E-UTRA ARFCN - Section Description: The E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number defines the carrier frequency used in an E-UTRAN cell for a given direction (UL or DL) in FDD or for both UL and DL directions in TDD. 9.2.2.21 E-UTRA ARFCN IE Semantics: The relation between EARFCN and carrier frequency (in MHz) are defined in TS 36.104 [25].
9.2.2.14 TAC IE Semantics: Tracking Area Code 9.2.2.5 TAC - Section Description: This information element is used to uniquely identify a Tracking Area within a PLMN.
9.2.2.6 RAN Area Code - Section Description: This IE defines the RAN Area Code.

9.2.2.40 Number of UL Symbols IE Semantics: Number of consecutive UL symbols in the end of the slot identified by Slot Index. If extended cyclic prefix is used, the maximum value is 11.

9.2.2.12 Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication IE Semantics: This IE indicates which E-UTRA control/reference signal resources are protected and are not subject to E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination. 9.2.2.29 Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication - Section Description: This IE indicates the resources allocated for E-UTRA DL and UL reference and control signals (hereby referred to as protected resources). This information is used in the process of E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination.
9.2.2.29 Activation SFN IE Semantics: Indicates from which SFN of the receiving node the resource allocation is valid.

9.2.2.29 Protected Resource List IE Semantics: The protected resource pattern is continuously repeated, and it is valid until stated otherwise or until replaced by a new pattern. The pattern does not apply in reserved subframes.
9.2.2.29 Protected Resource List Item IE Semantics: Each item describes one transmission pattern. A pattern may comprise several control signals.
9.2.2.29 Resource Type IE Semantics: Indicates whether the protected resource is E-UTRA DL non-CRS, E-UTRA CRS or E-UTRA UL.

9.2.2.29 Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint IE Semantics: The bitmap of REs occupied by the protected signal within one PRB. Each position in the bitmap represents an RE in one PRB; value “0” indicates "resource not protected", value “1” indicates "resource protected ". The first bit of the string corresponds to the RE with the smallest time and frequency index in the PRB, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. The length of the bit string equals the product of  and the length of PRB in time dimension, measured in REs.  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The intra-PRB pattern consisting of all “1”s is equivalent to PRB-level granularity.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Frequency Pattern IE Semantics: The bit string indicates in which PRBs inside carrier bandwidth the Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint applies. How often in time dimension this frequency pattern applies, depends on time periodicity of Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint. The first bit of the bit string corresponds to the PRB occupying the lowest subcarrier frequencies of the carrier bandwidth, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. Each position in the string represents a PRB; value “0” indicates " Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint does not appear in PRB", value “1” indicates "Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint appears in PRB". The length of the bit string equals the number of PRBs in the carrier bandwidth.
9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Time Pattern IE Semantics: The description of time periodicity of the Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Time-periodicity IE Semantics: Periodicity with which the periodic Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint repeats in time-dimension (1= every PRB (i.e. slot), 2=every other PRB (i.e. slot) etc.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Start Time IE Semantics: The time-position of the PRB inside the frame in which the periodic Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint appears for the first time. The value “1” corresponds to the receiving node’s slot 0 in subframe 0 in the receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN.
9.2.2.29 MBSFN Control Region Length IE Semantics: Length of control region in MBSFN subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.
9.2.2.29 PDCCH Region Length IE Semantics: Length of PDCCH region in regular subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.

9.2.2.29 Protected Resource List IE Semantics: The protected resource pattern is continuously repeated, and it is valid until stated otherwise or until replaced by a new pattern. The pattern does not apply in reserved subframes.
9.2.2.29 Protected Resource List Item IE Semantics: Each item describes one transmission pattern. A pattern may comprise several control signals.
9.2.2.29 Resource Type IE Semantics: Indicates whether the protected resource is E-UTRA DL non-CRS, E-UTRA CRS or E-UTRA UL.

9.2.2.29 Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint IE Semantics: The bitmap of REs occupied by the protected signal within one PRB. Each position in the bitmap represents an RE in one PRB; value “0” indicates "resource not protected", value “1” indicates "resource protected ". The first bit of the string corresponds to the RE with the smallest time and frequency index in the PRB, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. The length of the bit string equals the product of  and the length of PRB in time dimension, measured in REs.  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The intra-PRB pattern consisting of all “1”s is equivalent to PRB-level granularity.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Frequency Pattern IE Semantics: The bit string indicates in which PRBs inside carrier bandwidth the Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint applies. How often in time dimension this frequency pattern applies, depends on time periodicity of Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint. The first bit of the bit string corresponds to the PRB occupying the lowest subcarrier frequencies of the carrier bandwidth, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. Each position in the string represents a PRB; value “0” indicates " Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint does not appear in PRB", value “1” indicates "Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint appears in PRB". The length of the bit string equals the number of PRBs in the carrier bandwidth.
9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Time Pattern IE Semantics: The description of time periodicity of the Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Time-periodicity IE Semantics: Periodicity with which the periodic Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint repeats in time-dimension (1= every PRB (i.e. slot), 2=every other PRB (i.e. slot) etc.

9.2.2.29 Protected Footprint Start Time IE Semantics: The time-position of the PRB inside the frame in which the periodic Intra-PRB Protected Resource Footprint appears for the first time. The value “1” corresponds to the receiving node’s slot 0 in subframe 0 in the receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN.
9.2.2.29 MBSFN Control Region Length IE Semantics: Length of control region in MBSFN subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.
9.2.2.29 PDCCH Region Length IE Semantics: Length of PDCCH region in regular subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.

The first bit of the string corresponds to the RE with the smallest time and frequency index in the PRB, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. The length of the bit string equals the product of  and the length of PRB in time dimension, measured in REs.  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The first bit of the bit string corresponds to the PRB occupying the lowest subcarrier frequencies of the carrier bandwidth, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. section_list.name: Data Traffic Resource Indication
aoa: This IE indicates the intended data traffic resource allocation for E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination.
9.2.2.30 Activation SFN IE Semantics: Indicates from which SFN of the receiving node the agreement is valid.

9.2.2.31 Data Traffic Resources - Section Description: The Data Traffic Resources IE indicates the intended data traffic resource allocation for E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination. 9.2.2.31 Data Traffic Resources IE Semantics: The indication of resources allocated to E-UTRA PDSCH/PUSCH. Each position in the bit string represents a PRB pair in a subframe; value “0” indicates "resource not intended to be used for transmission", value “1” indicates "resource intended to be used for transmission ". The first bit of the bit string corresponds to the PRB pair occupying the lowest subcarrier frequencies of the carrier, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes. The first position of the Data Traffic Resources IE corresponds to the receiving node’s subframe 0 in a receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN. The length of the bit string is an integer multiple of  or , defined in TS 36.211 [10].

The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes. The first bit of the bit string corresponds to the PRB pair occupying the lowest subcarrier frequencies of the carrier, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes. The first position of the Data Traffic Resources IE corresponds to the receiving node’s subframe 0 in a receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN. The length of the bit string is an integer multiple of  or , defined in TS 36.211 [10].

9.2.2.30 Reserved Subframe Pattern IE Semantics: Indicates subframes in which the resource allocation does not hold. 9.2.2.32 Reserved Subframe Pattern - Section Description: The Reserved Subframe Pattern IE indicates the pattern of subframes in which the Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication and Data Traffic Resource Indication do not hold.
9.2.2.32 Subframe Type IE Semantics: Indicates what type of non-regular subframes the Reserved Subframe Pattern refers to (e.g. MBSFN).

9.2.2.32 Reserved Subframe Pattern IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a subframe. Value ‘0’ indicates “regular subframe”. Value ‘1’ indicates “reserved subframe”. For MBSFN subframes, the exception refers only to the non-control region of the subframe. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes. The first position of the Subframe Configuration IE corresponds to the receiving node’s subframe 0 in a receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN. The IE is ignored if received by the ng-eNB.
9.2.2.32 MBSFN Control Region Length IE Semantics: Length of control region in MBSFN subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.

section_list.name: Data Traffic Resources
aoa: 9.2.2.31 Data Traffic Resources IE Semantics: The Data Traffic Resources IE indicates the intended data traffic resource allocation for E-UTRA - NR Cell Resource Coordination. The indication of resources allocated to E-UTRA PDSCH/PUSCH. Each position in the bit string represents a PRB pair in a subframe; value “0” indicates "resource not intended to be used for transmission", value “1” indicates "resource intended to be used for transmission ". The first bit of the bit string corresponds to the PRB pair occupying the lowest subcarrier frequencies of the carrier, where the indexing first goes into the frequency domain. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes. The first position of the Data Traffic Resources IE corresponds to the receiving node’s subframe 0 in a receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN. The length of the bit string is an integer multiple of  or , defined in TS 36.211 [10].

section_list.name: Reserved Subframe Pattern
aoa: The Reserved Subframe Pattern IE indicates the pattern of subframes in which the Protected E-UTRA Resource Indication and Data Traffic Resource Indication do not hold.
9.2.2.32 Subframe Type IE Semantics: Indicates what type of non-regular subframes the Reserved Subframe Pattern refers to (e.g. MBSFN).

9.2.2.32 Reserved Subframe Pattern IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a subframe. Value ‘0’ indicates “regular subframe”. Value ‘1’ indicates “reserved subframe”. For MBSFN subframes, the exception refers only to the non-control region of the subframe. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes. The first position of the Subframe Configuration IE corresponds to the receiving node’s subframe 0 in a receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = Activation SFN. The IE is ignored if received by the ng-eNB.
9.2.2.32 MBSFN Control Region Length IE Semantics: Length of control region in MBSFN subframes. Expressed in REs, in the time dimension.

section_list.name: MR-DC Resource Coordination Information
aoa: CHOICE NG-RAN Node Resource Coordination Information

9.2.2.33 CHOICE NG-RAN Node Resource Coordination Information IE Semantics: The MR-DC Resource Coordination Information IE is used to coordinate resource utilisation between the M-NG-RAN node and the S-NG-RAN node.

9.2.2.33 E-UTRA Resource Coordination Information IE Semantics: E-UTRA resource coordination information 9.2.2.34 E-UTRA Resource Coordination Information - Section Description: The E-UTRA Resource Configuration Information IE indicates LTE resource allocation at ng-eNB used at the gNB to coordinate resource utilisation between M-NG-RAN-node and S-NG-RAN node.
9.2.2.34 EUTRA Cell ID IE Semantics: This IE indicates the sPCell. 9.2.2.8 E-UTRA CGI - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an E-UTRA cell (see TS 36.300 [12]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.8 E-UTRA Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the E-UTRA Cell Identity IE correspond to the ng-eNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.2).

9.2.2.34 UL Coordination Information IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a PRB pair in a subframe; value "0" indicates "PCell resource not intended to be used for transmission by the sending node", value "1" indicates "PCell resource intended to be used for transmission by the sending node". The bit string spans from the first PRB pair of the first represented subframe to the last PRB pair of the same subframe and then moves to the following PRBs in the following subframes in the same order. Each position is applicable only in positions corresponding to UL subframes. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes (maximum 40). The first position of the UL Coordination Information corresponds to subframe 0 in a radio frame where SFN = 0. The length of the bit string is an integer multiple of .  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The UL Coordination Information is continuously repeated.

9.2.2.34 DL Coordination Information IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a PRB pair in a subframe; value "0" indicates "PCell resource not intended to be used for transmission by the sending node", value "1" indicates "PCell resource intended to be used for transmission by the sending node". The bit string spans from the first PRB pair of the first represented subframe to the last PRB pair of the same subframe and then moves to the following PRBs in the following subframes in the same order. Each position is applicable only in positions corresponding to DL subframes. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes (maximum 40). The first position of the DL Coordination Information corresponds to the receiving node’s subframe 0 in a receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = 0. The length of the bit string is an integer multiple of .  is defined in TS 36.211 [10]. The DL Coordination Information is continuously repeated.
9.2.2.34 NR CGI IE Semantics: This IE indicates the assumed sPCell. 9.2.2.7 NR CGI - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an NR cell (see TS 38.300 [9]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.7 NR Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE correspond to the gNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.1).

9.2.2.36 E-UTRA Coordination Assistance Information - Section Description: The E-UTRA Coordination Assistance Information IE is provided by the ng-eNB and used by the gNB to determine further coordination of resource utilisation between the gNB and the ng-eNB.

9.2.2.33 NR Resource Coordination Information IE Semantics: NR resource coordination information 9.2.2.35 NR Resource Coordination Information - Section Description: The NR Resource Coordination Information IE indicates resources within the bandwidth of the ng-eNB sPCell which are not available for use by the ng-eNB and is used at the ng-eNB to coordinate resource utilisation between the gNB and the ng-eNB.
9.2.2.35 NR CGI IE Semantics: This IE indicates the sPCell. 9.2.2.7 NR CGI - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an NR cell (see TS 38.300 [9]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.7 NR Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE correspond to the gNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.1).

9.2.2.35 UL Coordination Information IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a PRB pair in a subframe; value "0" indicates "sPCell resource not intended to be used for transmission by the sending node", value "1" indicates "sPCell resource intended to be used for transmission by the sending node". The bit string spans from the first PRB pair of the first represented subframe to the last PRB pair of the same subframe and then moves to the following PRBs in the following subframes in the same order. Each position is applicable only in positions corresponding to UL subframes. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes (maximum 40). The first position of the UL Coordination Information corresponds to the receiving node’s subframe 0 in a receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = 0. The length of the bit string is an integer multiple of  . is defined in TS 36.211 [26]. The UL Coordination Information is continuously repeated.

9.2.2.35 DL Coordination Information IE Semantics: Each position in the bitmap represents a PRB pair in a subframe; value "0" indicates "sPCell resource not intended to be used for transmission by the sending node", value "1" indicates "sPCell resource intended to be used for transmission by the sending node". The bit string spans from the first PRB pair of the first represented subframe to the last PRB pair of the same subframe and then moves to the following PRBs in the following subframes in the same order. Each position is applicable only in positions corresponding to DL subframes. The bit string may span across multiple contiguous subframes (maximum 40). The first position of the DL Coordination Information corresponds to the receiving node’s subframe 0 in a receiving node’s radio frame where SFN = 0. The length of the bit string is an integer multiple of .  is defined in TS 36.211 [26]. The DL Coordination Information is continuously repeated.
9.2.2.35 EUTRA Cell ID IE Semantics: Reference cell for UL Coordination Information IE and DL Coordination Information IE.

9.2.2.37 NR Coordination Assistance Information - Section Description: The NR Coordination Assistance Information IE is provided by the gNB and used by the ng-eNB to determine further coordination of resource utilisation between the gNB and the ng-eNB.

aoa: 9.2.2.36 E-UTRA Coordination Assistance Information IE Semantics: The E-UTRA Coordination Assistance Information IE is provided by the ng-eNB and used by the gNB to determine further coordination of resource utilisation between the gNB and the ng-eNB.

section_list.name: NR Coordination Assistance Information
aoa: 9.2.2.37 NR Coordination Assistance Information IE Semantics: The NR Coordination Assistance Information IE is provided by the gNB and used by the ng-eNB to determine further coordination of resource utilisation between the gNB and the ng-eNB.

section_list.name: NE-DC TDM Pattern
aoa: The NE-DC TDM Pattern IE is provided by the gNB and used by the ng-eNB to determine UL/DL reference configuration indicating the time during which a UE configured with NE-DC is allowed to transmit.
ENUMERATED (sa0, sa1, sa2, sa3, sa4, sa5, sa6)
9.2.2.38 Subframe Assignment IE Semantics: Indicates DL/UL subframe configuration where sa0 points to Configuration 0, sa1 to Configuration 1 etc. as specified in TS 36.331 [14].
9.2.2.38 Harq Offset IE Semantics: Indicates a HARQ subframe offset that is applied to the subframes designated as UL in the associated subframe assignment, see TS 36.331 [14]

section_list.name: Interface Instance Indication
aoa: 9.2.2.39 Interface Instance Indication IE Semantics: The Interface Instance Indication identifies the interface instance the XnAP message is destined for. NOTE: The Interface Instance Indication is allocated so that it can be associated with an Xn-C interface instance. The Interface Instance Indication may identify more than one interface instance.

section_list.name: Intended TDD DL-UL Configuration NR
aoa: This IE contains the subcarrier spacing, cyclic prefix and TDD DL-UL slot configuration of an NR cell that a neighbour NG-RAN node needs to take into account for cross-link interference mitigation, when operating its own cells.
9.2.2.40 NR SCS IE Semantics: The values scs15, scs30, scs60 and scs120 corresponds to the sub carrier spacing in TS 38.104 [24].
9.2.2.40 NR Cyclic Prefix IE Semantics: The type of cyclic prefix, which determines the number of symbols in a slot.
ENUMERATED (ms0p5, ms0p625, ms1, ms1p25, ms2, ms2p5, ms3, ms4, ms5, ms10, ms20, ms40, ms60, ms80, ms100, ms120, ms140, ms160, …)
9.2.2.40 NR DL-UL Transmission Periodicity IE Semantics: The periodicity is expressed in the format msXpYZ, and equals X.YZ milliseconds.
9.2.2.40 Number of DL Symbols IE Semantics: Number of consecutive DL symbols at the beginning of the slot identified by Slot Index. If extended cyclic prefix is used, the maximum value is 11.
9.2.2.40 Number of UL Symbols IE Semantics: Number of consecutive UL symbols in the end of the slot identified by Slot Index. If extended cyclic prefix is used, the maximum value is 11.

section_list.name: Cell and Capacity Assistance Information NR
aoa: Cell and Capacity Assistance Information NR
The Cell and Capacity Assistance Information NR IE is used by the NG-RAN node to request information about NR cells and it includes information about cell list size capacity.
9.2.2.44 Maximum Cell List Size - Section Description: This IE indicates the maximum size the sending node can handle for a given cell list.
9.2.2.17 Cell Assistance Information NR - Section Description: The Cell Assistance Information IE is used by the NG-RAN node to request information about NR cells.
9.2.2.17 List of Requested NR Cells IE Semantics: Included when the NG-RAN node requests a limited list of served NR cells.
9.2.2.17 NR CGI IE Semantics: NR cell for which served NR cell information is requested. 9.2.2.7 NR CGI - Section Description: This IE is used to globally identify an NR cell (see TS 38.300 [9]).

9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity - Section Description: This IE indicates the PLMN Identity. 9.2.2.4 PLMN Identity IE Semantics: Digits 0 to 9 encoded 0000 to 1001, 1111 used as filler digit. Two digits per octet: - bits 4 to 1 of octet n encoding digit 2n-1 - bits 8 to 5 of octet n encoding digit 2n PLMN Identity consists of 3 digits from MCC followed by either: - a filler digit plus 2 digits from MNC (in case of 2 digit MNC) or - 3 digits from MNC (in case of 3 digit MNC).
9.2.2.7 NR Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE correspond to the gNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.1).
9.2.2.17 Complete Information Request Indicator IE Semantics: Included when the NG-RAN node requests the complete list of served cells for a gNB

9.2.2.7 NR Cell Identity IE Semantics: The leftmost bits of the NR Cell Identity IE correspond to the gNB ID (defined in subclause 9.2.2.1).
9.2.2.43 Complete Information Request Indicator IE Semantics: Included when the NG-RAN node requests the complete list of served cells for a ng-eNB

section_list.name: Cell Assistance Information E-UTRA

9.2.2.43 List of Requested E-UTRA Cells IE Semantics: Included when the NG-RAN node requests a limited list of served E-UTRA cells.
